Like the boys at the soul of the film itself going through what they're going through, the audience themselves are invited to take a step back and really mediate on what it is we truly think about what's transpiring before our eyes.

The story of the four boys is narrated to us by a certain Gordie Lachance, the later incarnation of whom is portrayed by Richard Dreyfuss in the then present day 1980s with Wil Wheaton playing the younger version from some thirty years previously. His friends, with whom he lives in a close knit Oregon community in the latter stages of the 1950s, are Chris Chambers (Phoenix); Teddy Duchamp (Feldman) and Vern Tessio (O'Connell), together forming a quartet of really well rounded, engaging characters whom end up in a flurry of situations both before and during the venturing out to a rural zone on the outskirts of town that it has been heard harbours the dead body of another young boy. LaChance sits idly in his vehicle to the side of a country road in the immediate opening, sighing with a tone of regret at a newspaper story detailing the death of someone. A group of kids cycle past him, they garner his attention and ours in that the following track-in on LaChance results in a flashing back to his own childhood which, like the physical manifestation of the boys whom just went by, has indeed passed him by.

The set up sees a somewhat bubbled existence within the Oregon town of Castle Rock established to be life's norm. The kids spend most of their spare time in a secluded tree house away from everybody else laughing and joking at each other's expense in-between humbling information usually linked to troubles at home provided by the narrator on each of the other three involved. The sense of the community being closely knitted feels prominent, a scene showing one of the boys in Chris receiving a harmless enough lift from a truck driver to meet up with one of the other boys establishing a worry-free sense of togetherness in this small, enclosed world of your bog-standard adolescent living through crude humour; practical jokes; the coming to terms with home truths which itself comes with an odd sense of alienation from one's parents as well as the threats posed from local bullies.

The few or so days they spend out of this enclosed circle of a functioning world that is their home town does not dictate precisely where it is they will all end up in life, but Stand by Me is not a film aiming for expansive frills revolving around somebody's entire life story. Instead, effort has been inserted into detailing what goes on in and around the local area of forestry located on the outskirts of said town and how more immediate attitudes can shift. An amusing short-story to do with Vern's inability to find a jar of money he secretly buried in the dirt under his house's porch acts as the catalyst for the film to revolve around these four kids and their venturing out yonder across train tracks and through the countryside in an attempt to find the dead body of a boy whom was supposedly struck down by a train. His brother Billy (Siemaszko), one of a number of gang dwelling bullies headed by Kiefer Sutherland's Ace Merrill, informs a friend of his of said body with Verne underneath eavesdropping.

With win of the info; barely enough supplies to see out the journey; a charming script which allows time for these four to bond and share small talk with each other as well as a young, abundance of energy in tow: the boys set off on a trip which they will remember for as long as they are alive. Reiner has them predominantly stick to some train tracks; their doing so in a bid to eventually guide them to their prize a somewhat iconographic deployed. The tracks below them are representative of the firm, formulated, entrenched arc they're on in both a literal and metaphorical sense in that they can lead only to what they discover in the form of the dead body as well as inside of themselves in relation to the journey itself. There are no deviations, not on the permanently fixed road upon which they tread nor the metaphorical road the four of them have landed themselves on: all paths lead to what discoveries must occur up ahead. Under Reiner's careful, watchful and astute direction combined with a worthy screenplay; Stand by Me stands as a wonderful documenting of four young characters undergoing a rounded process of realisation and hardship.

review_title: Not as good as I expected
review_detailed_main:
This movie, Stand By Me, is a retelling of a novella by my favorite author, Steven King, an one of my favorite stories ever. So, anxiously, I picked up this movie and...

Hated it. Oh, I've seen bad movies before, and this was not the worst, but it wasn't a movie I'd come back to. After seeing The Shawshank Redemption, another King novella in the same book, I expected more great things. Alas...

I'd like to finsih this by saying that the acting was not bad, but it is mostly just the director' uncanny ability to draw out the best. So, I must give this a 4 out of a possible 10, and pray that people who liked this see Shawshank Redemption and THEN watch it. See the difference!

review_title: It's my favourite film, the best.........
review_detailed_main: I love this film it's my favourite film of all. All the actors are incredible especially River Phoenix - it always makes me cry when watching the ending thinking about what happened to him. I really wish he had lived on so he could have continued to make such fantastic films even though I haven't seen all his other films I still think he is the best actor even if he was before my time. The other performances in this should also be recognised as they were all fabulous and Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell have the perfect chemistry of such close friends. Keiffer Sufferland really does come across as the scary bully and is very intimidating from the view of Gordie.

I see a lot of movies and just a few movies have touched my heart like this one. Even though I'm only 16 now, I'm already missing the freshness of innocent childhood, and I'm really missing my old friends. This movie made me remember how much life means to me and how much I must thank all my friends, because they've helped me go through really hard moments.

These movie has a lot of things to offer the public. Don't consider this masterpiece just a "movie" it contains the support and freshness childhood means it's something absolutely beautiful. A movie to treasure forever in the hearts of all the people that have seen it.

This movie is a lot like the sandlot but for older kids. It's fun and perfect to watch during summer, but it's also emotional and touches on darker topics. It dives much deeper into the characters than the sandlot does. The acting is also amazing. I love this movie.

This movie was like that baseball girl, who got thrown out at home. Except there aren't any girls in it except for maybe this waitress who looks like Big Bird and thinks a gun and a cherry bomb are the same thing. These 4 kids want to visit this other kid in a different town, so they make up excuses to leave home and walk around railroad tracks. That other kid's dead though, so it was definitely a good idea to bring a comb.

One of the kids is like Crisco. Fat in the can, and digging holes under the porch because you can't buy much food for 7 cents. You get to hear about an even fatter kid who can make people puke on each other, because cartoons can't beat up real guys.

I don't really want to think about guys prancing through the woods singing songs about lollipops or sitting around in wet tighty-whiteys yanking bugs off each other. And I definitely wouldn't want anyone Standing By ME if I had to pick giant swamp-roaches out of my undies.

review_title: I understand why many people like this movie, I just don't agree that it's a 10/10...
review_detailed_main:
I saw Stand By Me for the first time maybe 10 years ago. I then gave it 5/10. I felt I had to watch it again now, to see if I really think it's a 5/10, and I don't stand by that rating entirely, pun intended. I will raise the rating to 6/10, but not more than that.

I can agree that the characters are interesting and it aims to find a bit of everyone in each boy and the film achieves that. Everyone probably identifies with these characters and can relate to their own youth.

However, I find the story very boring. The movie is pretty predictable, and there's something about it that doesn't make an impact on me. It never satisfies me or entertains me that much. Except the ending. I liked the ending very much. The ending was probably the best part of the movie. It was dark and sad, yet realistic. The ending is why I raise the rating.

These kinda movies come along very rarely. This is my personal all-time favorite movie. The actors are very talented, especially Wil Wheaton (Gordie) and River Phoenix (Chris) who are my 2 favorite actors. It is based on a Stephen King novella called "The Body" and I have read the book and it was fantastic also. The script was put together very well and they done very good on the screen play. All of the actors were very young whenever they shot this and they all showed extreme maturity. I think a lot of people can relate to this movie because it cuts so deep into the heart. I wish that I could have a best friend like Gordie had Chris and Chris had Gordie. Yeah, I have a best friend, but we aren't "best" best friends... If you have not seen this movie you need to go out and find it because im sure that this movie will change your life like it did mine.

review_title: Truly sweet but a bit unoriginal
review_detailed_main:
This is a movie in hand if you are feeling down. It is bright, innocent, cute and it truly cherishes the meaning of friendship. I found it enjoyable and well acted but still...it is so extremely typical American film, very typical with some light chlicés. The part where one of the boys tells a story was somewhat stupid. Why do so many American films want to add moments of dumb people playing with food and vomiting it out totally un-naturally? I just don´t get it!

But don´t get me wrong. The story was a wonderful mix of sunnyness and emotions. I´m sure that expecially young boys will be delighted and why not the whole family? All of the young actors were natural and good. Expecially I was impressed by River Phoenix and Will Wheaton´s performances. They delivered rich emotions and cried painfully real. Yes, they were good.

But we must admit that this movie has been made again. The Sandlot, Now and Then (a girl version), Little giants, they all are very similar to Stand by Me. It´s a very enjoyable, colorful, 50´s spirited, cute family film. I give it ***from*****

review_title: The most honest portrayal of how 12-year-old boys really are. One of my all time favorites.
review_detailed_main:
This is such a great movie. It is a very brave, and entertaining comedy/drama, that actually has the courage to show 12-year-olds as they really are, and doesn't clean it up for the whole family like most movies of this kind do. It's a hilarious comedy at times, but is also very heartwarming and tragic.

Most of you know the story. The set up for the adventure is when four pre-teen boys learn about the whereabouts of a missing local kid's dead body. They end up going on a twenty mile quest to find the body, and hope to become heroes.

Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton) is a sensitive, and intellectual kid who lives in the shadow of his dead older brother Dennis (John Cusack), who was the only one in his family who actually understood him. Everybody acknowledges to him about how well his brother played football, which makes Gordie's pain even worse. His parents don't seem to care about him anymore, and he feels that his dad hates him. He is a great storyteller, and his best friend Chris Chambers (River Phoenix), gives him hope and encouragement.

Chris Chambers is an abused kid who comes from a family of lowlife thugs, including his cruel older brother Eyeball (Bradley Gregg). Chris is a good kid, and although he has made some bad choices, he still remains a very positive character. His family's bad reputation alienates him from society, and he doesn't have much of a chance in life because of it. In one of the most heartbreaking scenes, he tells Gordie about how a teacher cold-heartedly took advantage of his bad reputation, when he tried to return some money he stole.

Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) is a somewhat crazy and disturbed kid, who loves his dad (only because he was a WW2 veteran), who nearly burned off his ear on a stove. Teddy is sarcastic, and rude, but in a rather nice way, and would still be a good friend.

Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell) is the main source of the movie's humor. He is a squeamish, cry-baby, scaredy-cat. He insists that Gordie doesn't tell any horror stories, and is worried about the dumbest things (a coyote, a dog, the results of a coincidental coin flip). He is really just a tag along, who is always being picked on by the rest of the gang, particularly Teddy (who frequently punches him, and gives him two more for flinching). He is the one who learns about the body's whereabouts, and gives the others the idea for the quest.

The dead body is really just a set up for a series of adventures that the boys have on their journey. They nearly get run over by a train on a bridge in one scene, and in another they face a mythical junkyard dog. And when they find the body, they have to face a ruthless gang of older kids led by Ace (Keifer Sutherland), who are also after the body. They have campfires, and share a bond that is very touching. Any guy who has ever had a group of friends can relate to the antics of these four boys. They cuss like sailors, smoke, and do other things that they wouldn't do with their parents around. The way these boys talk, and act is very accurate to the way kids their age are (though their insults are very old and 50's). I was their age not long ago, and was exactly like that. The ultimate example of the phrase "boys will be boys" is depicted in hilarious detail in this film. There is a sequence of gross- out humor when Gordie tells a story he wrote about a massively obese kid nicknamed "Lardass," who takes revenge on his tormentors by entering a pie-eating contest with funny, but gross intentions. That scene is very, very disgusting, but is a silly, lighthearted way, and when you see it, you'll understand what I mean. Boys really love that stuff.

The movie has a very tragic ending, that is still heartwarming. It really makes you cherish your friends more, and brings you closer to them. Every pre-teen should see this, but unfortunately, few kids I know actually enjoyed it. They usually thought it was corny and boring. This movie may be slightly sappy at times, but it is all for good purpose, and makes you feel great. Also, it is the complete opposite of boring. Every scene is interesting in some way. The scenes are either hilarious, heart-wrenching, or heartwarming. Sometimes even suspenseful. I cherish this movie, and recommend it to EVERYONE. Watch it now, and love it. 9/10.

Stand By Me is rated R for Language Including Sexual References, and Some Crude Humor. Sex: 4/10 Violence: 5/10 Swearing: 7/10 Drugs: 5/10

review_title: Revenge of the 80's: The Works of Stephen King meet River Phoenix Superstar!
A Beautiful Movie.. Truly Worth Watching!
review_detailed_main: So, I watched this movie and it was so good.. Everything seems so good.. The acting, the story(by the Legend Stephen King based on his novella "The Body") and of course the screenplay is so beautiful.. The movie makes you feel like you are a part of the characters.. It's a story of true friendship.. The Music/Soundtrack is good but the song playing in the credits is just mesmerizing(Stand By Me By Ben E. King). You should definitely watch this movie..

Stand by me is a timeless classic that will never age. Even though the story is very simple: 'Four 12 year-oldish friends go on a 2 day journey searching for a dead body of a boy they know' it is much more than that.

First of all, the actors are perfectly cast and one of the reasons this movie works so well is the brilliant acting and amazing chemistry between the four leads: River Phoenix, Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. They do such a genuine and believable job here at such a young age and their charisma and characters immediately suck you in and give you a nostalgic feeling that stays with you long after the credits have rolled.

The supporting cast is also terrific. The cobras are hysterical with some of their one-liners, Kiefer Sutherland is amazingly believable as the stereotypical bully, and even John Cusack's small, yet memorable scenes add to this wonderful film.

Stand By Me is a funny and nostalgic movie, with some of the best one-liners and memorable scenes that will leave an impression on the viewer. I couldn't help but want to call up my childhood friends and discuss one of the best movies I've seen in years.

10/10

Stand By Me is a great film about kids, and the adventures and troubles they get into. Stand By Me showcases all of them, wrapped in drama, sadness, and humor. Stand By Me is a great film to have under your belt. Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell work so well together, it's like they've always been friends. And together, with Keifer Sutherland, it makes a fantastic group. Not to mention director Rob Reiner, he knows how to direct, because he has been directed. "all In The Family" wouldn't be the same if it wasn't for Michael "Meathead" Stivick (SP). Anyways, back to Stand By Me. Fantastic. Good for anyone to watch. 10 Stars for this coming-of-age flick!

I cannot recall a time I have ever seen a movie with a plot as simple as this that still managed to be so effective and powerful. I felt connected to the main characters of the movie who were all likeable in their own ways. The villain characters may have been shallow but that is more than made up for in the excellent acting and chemistry between the main characters. I laughed during this movie and I even cried by the end of it. This is a small gem that should not be missed out on and I'm glad I found it and gave it a chance! Stephen King really is one of the greatest storytellers of our time even when he isn't doing the horror he is most well known for.

review_title: An easy-to-watch meander through a distant memory.
review_detailed_main: Considered one of the seminal 'coming of age' movies, 'Stand By Me (1986)' represents one of Stephen King's least horrific stories in a generally wholesome and appealing way but isn't as immensely gripping or thematically rich, at least in its final presentation, as its reputation would have you believe. Maybe a lot of this comes down to its kind of unrelatable core conceit and some of the stranger twists and turns of its narrative, though the overall experience is by no means a negative one and essentially represents an easy-to-watch, well-acted meander through a distant memory. 7/10

review_title: A film need not be expensive to be Great
review_detailed_main:
It was 1987 when I first went to see this flick and in fact wondered why I saw it THREE times? Later it occurred to me this was a coming of age film and anyone from 18-80 who is a man, probably has some unconscious baggage about such hard, yet unforgettable experiences.

I recently got a 50 inch plasma so thought, why not get some of the films I recall as classic.

I very much enjoyed River Phoenix as a kid, who was 16, but in the film looked not a day over 14.

The sad and prophetic part, is where River walks away and vanishes down the road forever.

Isn't this what time does for us? Just as we realize we have had an experience, its over and gone, who knows where.

review_title: One of the best coming to age movies 8/10
A "coming of age" movie about 12 year old boys which is NOT suitable for kids!!

review_detailed_main:
Scrolling thru my collection and said,"What the hell." Probably the 3rd or 4th time I've watched this excellent movie, but I didn't care. It's a goodie. Great story and early performances by River Pheonix, Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. Keifer Sutherland plays a good - cheap, dimestore hood, as well.

I grew up in the 70's, so I missed this time frame by about 10 years, but it's a really good growing up story. I agree with the quote at the end of the movie. Plus, the soundtrack was perfect.

Stephen King said that it was the best adaptation of one of his books that he'd ever seen. I've read the short novel, and the screenplay stays true. If you've not seen this, you need to.

I'll give it a strong 8 out of 10.

Stand by Me adapted from the 1981 novella, written by Stephen King, The Body, is a allegory for any person that wants to spend the last weekend with their chums and engage on an odyssey that demonstrates honesty and aspiration. The nexus between the four main friends is both kind and noble. The way the film's narrator, who is played by legendary film actor Richard Dryffus (apologize for any misspelled words and erroneous grammar)who plays one of the young boys grown up as a writer, and how he sees in the beginning of the film those two boys on the bike allows him to reflect on his childhood and how friendship is eternal. The last ten minutes of the film, for me, are the most memorable and emotional when Chris Chanmbers, played by the late River Phoenix, is described by Richard Dryfus as being killed to try to settle a dispute, which reflects Mr. Chambers kind and conciliatory character, which was greatly accentuated by Mr. Phoenix understanding and passionate role. Thank you to Rob Reiner, Stephen King and the entire cast and filmmakers working on the film.

review_title: Not as good as I expected, considering its reputation
Stand by Me was a movie that truly blew me out of my socks.
review_detailed_main:
Stand by Me was a movie that truly blew me out of my socks. I saw it first when I was very young and I thought it was great, but completely forgot about it. Over the years, I thought less and less about it until I came across it again one day. I popped it in to see what I had forgotten about, and I found myself crying more than once. It sent a message that children should be receiving very early on. It's a movie about friendship and loyalty. I think my favorite scene was the 'Milk Money' scene. I found myself crying with Christopher Chambers about his dramatic loss and how everyone thought nothing of the 'low-life Chambers kid.'

This movie is essentially about four boys looking towards one goal. To be a hero by finding the missing body of Ray Brower and to be redeemed in their town's eyes. And when they set out on their 2-day trek, they learn things about each other that they never knew before. They learn that in each other's eyes they're all equal, and that's all that matters. They learn that they don't need to be redeemed in each other's eyes, because all of them have enough issues with themselves to be able to worry about the issues they have with their friends. But when the rival gang sets out with the same goal and they meet in that last scene, the whole movie pulls together to its ultimate climax. And this group of boys makes for a fun, dramatic and hilarious movie. Teddy Duchamp and Chris Chambers, both doomed to a life of misery by their deranged or angry fathers. Vern Tessio, the sacredly cat with a brother in their rival gang, and Gordie Lachance, perhaps one of my favorite characters in this movie, and the narrator. Gordie is the sensitive writer who just wants a little love from his parents after his brother died in a jeep accident. He was one of the characters that made me cry most, along with Chris.

Chris and Gordie are the best of friends, which is something that I think sends out a good message as well. Having a best friend whose shoulder you can cry on and who will always try to be there with you if you ever, in slightly dramatic terms, have a mental breakdown.

This movie is highly recommended. Definitely worth seeing, as it has turned into one of my favorites. Especially that one last line:

'I never had friends later on in life like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anybody?'

review_title: My new favorite River Phoenix movie
review_detailed_main: I've seen tons of teenager movies in my years, and this is one of the better ones. Plus, it's my second River Phoenix movie. I watched this one Saturday night and was pleasantly surprised. Good acting, relatable themes, plus a journey to the truth. It's been spoofed in various sitcoms that followed, including The Simpsons and Family Guy. The other River Phoenix movie I enjoyed was Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade, but I'd say this is my new favorite. It gave me a chance to know more about the late actor and his skills. Thank you, River.

The thing that makes this movie so great for me is the dynamics between the characters, especially between Chris and Gordy. This movie portrays their relationship, along with the other friends in the group, really well in the 1 and a half hour that you watch. I would give a 10/10 but the ending wasn't my favorite, it's not terrible and I understand it, just not my type of ending personally.

The intense moments in this movie are really well done in my opinion and the young actors (at the time) did a really good job in showing how intense and emotional some events can be.

I really liked this movie, give it a watch when you can.

review_title: A movie without one authoritative line of dialogue - miss it
review_detailed_main:
A complete waste of time. From the opening to the end, a narrator (it sounds like Richard Dreyfus's voice) utters cliché after cliché.

I could parse it and present several examples but one will suffice since it isn't worth more time than that. When a junk yard owner insults a boy and his friends drag him away he calls for them to come back. For what? This would not and does not happen in real life. The mean old man should laugh. That's how it happens in life and how it should have be written but since the "author" had to present us with the bonding of the boys (saving one from suicide wasn't enough) he couldn't leave "the plan," the plan he no doubt read in his copy of "Screen Writing For Dummies." The author seems to know exactly nothing about people except this: he wants to be a writer. In one pathetic scene (author's massage!) one of the boys suggest he might write about their pathetic little souls if he grows up to write.

Why not? There was quite an important event they were witnesses to and, if you can't write about that, what can you write about?... assuming one can write.

But this author can't. Still, the movie is something of a miracle. How did someone with such a bad script get the money to make this high-school level fluff? It's one thing to write about childhood but shouldn't the writer grow up first? Shouldn't he, at some point along the way, have learned something that can inform his important event with meaning?

review_title: "I Won't Cry, I Won't Cry, No, I Won't Shed A Tear..."

review_detailed_main: Rob Reiner's mid-80s breakthrough has aged wonderfully. Although parts dip into overt sentimentality (the John Cusack flashbacks feel a tad over-egged) it is a superbly paced and excellently shot drama brimming with excellent lines and memorable moments. The characters are rich and still feel fairly un-stereotypical and the performances are engaging and natural. It's rock solid basically - here the well-observed King gang-of-lads dynamic gets centre stage without any of the creepy stuff. Certain sequences still have a wild tension to them and the 50's jukebox soundtrack gives it a magically vivid sort of life that's hard to define, one of those rare period films which have an uncanny accuracy about them.

review_title: Stand By Me a 1986 film. Based on The Body by: Stephen King directed by: Rob Riener
I just rewatched this film and it's still just as good as the first time
review_detailed_main:
I just rewatched this film and it is just as good as the first time. I'm impressed by the age of the actors in this film and how amazing their performances are. River Phoenix has a moment with Wil Wheaton where he is pouring out his emotions to him. This scene just makes you want to cry, but it also show's you the emotional maturity that these kids had at such a young age.

The idea of fleeting friendship is what I think about when I watch this film. The way you can be so close with a certain group of people and in a moment that can change. This film does a good job at presenting this idea through the eyes of younger children.

It was very rare. I used to sit down with my nephew and watched goldies from the 80s, which he found dull and boring. I finally hit jackpot with Stand By Me. It seems the best Stephen King movies is about life, not the supernatural. Based on the short story "The Body", it tells the simple story of 4 friends going on a road trip to find the body of a dead kid. It's all about friendship, and loosing innocence, with a menacing Kiefer Sutherland luring with his croonies in the background. Starring some young, up and coming actors, you can't stop to think what happened to they're own future, when you watch it. The ending, were River Phoenix walks away and slowly dissapears, always make me shiver. Almost a foreboding for his tragic future. But beyond all, this is a story about the last tour for 4 friends, before they eventually split up. Just like life, you have childhood friends you share unforgettable memories with, but you just loose touch, and life goes on.

This story is that children, Gordie, Chris, Teddy, Vern venture in order to find a dead body. Through this adventure, they make deep friendship and develop as an adult.

This film develops by Gordie's flashback. I think the flashback style tell something that we can get in only our childhood. I sometimes felt bore because they just go to adventure. However, I could find innocence, curiosity, invincibility, and mutability peculiar to children.

My favorite point of this film is music, for example Lollipop", "Yakety Yak" and "Stand by Me". These soundtracks make film lively. I think nice choice of music.

Though this work was made in 1986, it is famous even now. I could understand this film is called a masterpiece. I think it has great ambition and nostalgia.

Stand by Me is a timeless portrayal of childhood, weaving together friendship and nostalgia in a deeply resonant way. It's a coming-of-age drama that's earned its spot among the best in its genre. What makes it special is the genuine performances of its young cast and how it nails every aspect of filmmaking to capture those unforgettable moments.

Based on Stephen King's novella and narrated by a writer reminiscing about his youth after a friend's passing, the story follows four boys on a journey to find the body of a missing child, hoping for local fame. But it becomes much more-a journey of self-discovery, friendship, and moral courage.

Rob Reiner's direction is top-notch, giving the film a seamless structure and a warm atmosphere. The screenplay keeps the characters innocent while delving into deeper themes. The cinematography adds emotional depth, and the editing keeps you engaged. The music choices fit perfectly with the storytelling.

The young ensemble, including Will Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell, deliver standout performances. Wheaton and Phoenix especially shine in their roles. Even Richard Dreyfuss, in a brief appearance as the older version of Wheaton's character, adds a poignant touch.

Decades after its release, Stand by Me still hits home, celebrating childhood innocence, friendship, and youthful curiosity. It's a heartfelt tribute to those years when friendships were pure and selfless. A journey worth taking for audiences of any age.

review_title: A very enjoyable film, with good performances throughout.
review_detailed_main:
Watching "Stand By Me" for the third time (but the first time in at least five years), I found myself enjoying it this time more than I did the first or second time I watched it, and I'm not sure why.

The performances are quite good considering the young age of the actors involved. Although the dialog is corny at times (i.e. "Stop it!"...if you've seen the film, you know what I mean. And who thought up that horrible last line to Lachance's book at the end of the movie?), on the whole, "Stand By Me" is a very enjoyable film that I would recommend to anyone, especially those who were children at the time that the story takes place.

I was disappointed at the end of the film and my wife too. I didn´t think that it could end so simply. The story is very thin and lives especially from typical kid stories or adventures. The movie never gets really chilling and also the time till they find the dead body is too long. Too easy and no big surprises when finally the kids found the body. In the whole film there were one or two funny scenes but believe me that´s all. I noted this movie from imdb critics and i have to say that they are partly too overrated. Rent it before you decide to buy it. Fortunately I only rent it but you won´t miss anything and it´s better you save the money for another good DVD. For these reasons we gave for the second time a 1/10. The other one was for "Memento".

review_title: Like my childhood. Except the body
review_detailed_main: I think this film is so great is because a lot of people especially males can see echos of their own lives in it. It reminds me of when i was around that age with my mates. Playing in local creeks and the bush etc. I hadn't really watched it right through till recently in my 60's and even though it's in rural America it rings true. All 4 boys are good in it and the older kids especially Kiefer Sutherland play their parts well. There are many memorable scenes like the train and the leeches and the lard ass story is a good one. I like how it ends with the classic song and it's true that friendships around 12 can be the strongest of your life.

review_title: I Never Had Any Friends Later On Like The Ones I Had When I Was Twelve. Jesus, Does Anyone?
It's a great movie that never gets old
review_detailed_main: This is a very amusing movie. Seeing those boys on an adventure that's funny, entertaining and meaningful all at once is just a great way to spend your time. This movie also shows that you don't need thousands of expensive effects to make something wonderful. The script alone can make a big difference. The humor in this movie is great - I tell you go watch this movie now. DO IT !!!

review_title: Great coming of age film set in a safe harbor town of the pacific northwest.........
I don't shut up, I grow up and when i look at you i throw up!
review_detailed_main: Stand by Me is my favorite movie of all times. River Phoenix glows as Chris Chambers. He is so believable, you should just watch the movie to see him. Will Wheaton also gives an outstanding performance. Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell shine in supporting roles. This was just a jumping off point for these guys but, it also had some big names. John Cusack is given about 5 minutes of screen time in flash backs as Gordie(Will Wheaton)and Keifer Surtherland plays the bad to the bone leader of the cobras. Awesome Movie and Awesome Cast.

Stand By Me is the tale of four token young lads: The token slick leader, the token normal but, conflicted one, the token weird, kooky one, and the token chubby, wussy one.

Within their venture, these hardy pals come across token future-self narration, a token savage dog that turns out not to be savage after all, token high school bullies, a token small town, token tomfoolery, token unbridled roasting, token campfire stories, token daddy issues, token near-death experiences that are played for thrills, token moments of sentimentality between the buds, and a token windup that's intended to get you riled up with tears.

Wait. I've just been informed that this story is the origin of all these token(s). Subtract the token(s) I wrote, I suppose. (Verdict: B)

review_title: A nostalgic and sensitive motion picture with very good young actors
review_detailed_main:
This is a brilliant and touching story , although sometimes results to be slow-moving and tiring , but resulting to be developed with real intelligence and extreme sensibility . In the picture is treated ethic and moral themes narrated with great sense of fairness and ductility . After the death of one of his friends, a writer (Richard Dreyfuss) recounts a childhood journey with his intimate friends (Wil Wheaton , Corey Feldman, River Phoenix , Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell , all of them ready as future stars) to find the body of a missing boy. As a group of friends search for the body of a missing teenager after one of them overhears his oldest brother ,who claims to have seen it . Unusually , the story is narrated by one of the boys , now in middle age . For some, it's the last real taste of innocence, and the first real taste of life . But for everyone, it's the time that memories are made of !.

A simple and plain plot but there's a lot more to the movie in the basic script. The search for the missing body becomes something of an odyssey for the boys and more an adventure than even they expected . It turns out to be an enjoyable and really perceptible tale which heightened by the late Fifties used in the musical score . Interpretations are pretty good , as protagonists play agreeable kiddies who will have to face off traumatic truths . Performances from the young kids as sensitive and agreeable boys are nice , they're newcomers and would have much success years later , some of them becoming into first-class world stars . Based on the novella "The Body" by Stephen King who delivers some self-biographic remarks and interesting storyline from Bruce A. Evans and Raynold Gideon. Stephen King collaborated with director Rob Reiner who named his production company "Castle Rock" after a fictional town created by Stephen King and the two have worked as a team on several movies together. Under Castle Rock Entertainment, Reiner went to direct Oscar-nominated films When Harry Met Sally, Misery, and A Few Good Men . In ¨Stand by me¨not always the sad device works, but it succeeds enough here , as it doesn't interfere with the slow down story. While filming the scene in Stand By Me (1986) in which Gordie and Vern are being chased by a train, Rob couldn't get Wil Wheaton and Jerry O'Connell to look frightened enough, so after a take, Reiner proceeded to yell at them until they began to cry , he then filmed the scene over again.

It contains excellent and stirring soundtrack by Jack Nitzsche , accompanied by emotive and classy 50s' songs. Besides , exceptional and awesome cinematography by Thomas Del Ruth, being stunningly shown on the marvelous outdoors in the country from Veneta, Eugene, Franklin, Brownsville, Oregon, Row River Trail, Gooseline Railroad, Cottage Grove, Oregon, Eagle Mountain , Burney, McCloud River Railroad, McCloud, California, USA . The motion picture was compellingly directed by Rob Reiner. Of all the films he has directed, he considers Stand By Me (1986) as his masterpiece and his favorite film. Reiner as best friends in high school with Richard Dreyfuss, whom he later directed in this stunning Stand By Me . Reiner directed three of the movies ranked in American Film Institute's list of top 100 U. S. love stories in 2002: When Harry met Sally... (1989) , The president y Miss Wade (1995) and The Princess Bride (1987) . And Rob directed 3 actors in Oscar nominated performances: Kathy Bates, Jack Nicholson, and James Woods ; Bates won for her performance in Misery (1990). Rob Reiner has directed two films that have been selected for the National Film Registry by the Library of Congress as being "culturally, historically or aesthetically" significant: This Is Spinal Tap (1984) and The Princess Bride (1987). Rating Stand By Me : 7/10 . Better than average , well wort watching .

It's hard to put in to words how much I honestly despise this film. It wasn't funny, it wasn't touching, it didn't show any "coming of age" at all, it didn't show much bonding....... and don't even get me started on that ending!
I've watched this movie 80 times and love it more today than I did when it first came out. Absolute classic that I'll watch hundreds of times more until the day I die.

review_title: me and bfl watched. cried in each others arms

review_detailed_main: As previously stated this is my favorite movie. There are multiple reasons i love this movie but the one that stands out the most is how much I can relate to it. Its honestly such a fun movie to watch with your close friends. Its definitely one of those movies that makes you feel good. HIGHLY RECCOMENDED.

Not only is this film highly entertaining, funny and well-moralised, but it keeps the viewer entranced. This has to be my favourite film. The boys were terrifically cast, especially River Phoenix as Chris Chambers, and you would have never guessed that chubby little Vern was infact Jerry O'Connel. The story line is hilarious and the adventure that the boys have, even though it only lasted a few days, they came back as different people. If you haven't seen this movie, I absolutely highly recommend it, it'll soon become one of your favourites. 11 out of 10!

Too short and very predictable, but if you grew up in a small town in the 50s, 60s or 70s you can relate to this film.

Simpler times when you spent your days with your friends riding your bikes or hanging out in front of the store.

Adventures were fuelled by imagination. No cable, no computers and no cell phones. You went home when it started to get dark and safety was rarely a concern.

Stand By Me is a little sappy and quite predictable, what really makes it great is the memories it brings back of your own childhood.

review_title: Genuinely Warm And, With More Than A Few Dark Shadows
review_detailed_main: The two most loved Stephen King adaptations aren't from the type of fiction for which he's best known; but like The Shawshank Redemption, the influence of horror lies deep within this beautifully crafted film. From the McGuffin of a dead body to the Pythonesque gross-out of the cherry pie eating contest, this may wear the clothes of a gentle-spirited coming-of-age tale, but the shadows cast by death, relationships and the slowly looming responsibilities of adulthood are longer and more profound than our memories of this film may let us think. But it's still - all these years later - a genuinely warm, truthful and witty film touching on the universal experience of the friendships we cherish as we move through childhood.

review_title: Solid coming of age film but not a masterpiece by any means
review_detailed_main:
I found this film to be a quite solid and entertaining product of Hollywood. However, it was certainly not a work of art and neither a masterpiece of drama. Expect a simple story that is well executed in the traditional Hollywood mold but it is far away from being a truly powerful film and a realistic portrayal of childhood. In fact, the kids in the film look more like adults or kids playing adults in a movie, than actual kids. That is a general problem with films portraying children since adults write the script and therefore they make all the characters act and talk like adults.

Try watching Miyazaki's Kiki's Delivery Service for a coming of age film featuring 12-13 year old kids in a much more realistic fashion and also in a much more artistically sophisticated fashion as well.

This movie opens so many different emotions in peoples hearts. It works on so man different levels. Everyone with a soul can relate to this movie enjoying a long summer with your friends and facing something scary and coming together when the going gets tuff. This is a rare and emotional film about the experiences of growing up and what kids face. Stand by me has to be the best coming of age film every maybe even the best all round film. The cast did a great job in creating a atmosphere that makes us think back to our childhood. i am only 16 and even now i am starting to loose the inocence of youth and growing up. My friends and i were actually like this round about when i was 12. we looked out for each other and then as time went on we started to go our separate ways. I never had any other friends later on in life like the ones i did when i was 12 Jesus does anyone?

Based on Stephen King's brief tale, Stand By Me follows four teenage friends (Wil Wheaton's Gordie, River Phoenix's Chris, Corey Feldman's Teddy, and Jerry O'Connell's Vern) as they embark on a trip to discover a dead body - with the film later (and mainly) detailing their numerous adventures along the manner.It's an extremely simple premise that Rob Reiner uses to a positive effect for the most part, as the filmmaker does a superb job of establishing both the small town atmosphere of the film and the friendship between the boys - with the personable, thoroughly engaging work of the four stars perpetuating the consistently affable vibe of the film in terms of the latter.There is little doubt, however, that the decidedly deliberate sensitivities of Reiner, coupled with the episodic bent of the script of Raynold Gideon and Bruce A. Evans, ensure that the first half of the film is not quite as electrifying as one might have hoped, as it is clear that some sequences are ultimately far better off than others.With the boys ' attempts to cross the railway bridge securely within the opening hour of the film, surely standing as a highlight. The palpable chemistry among the four children, in particular the rock-solid friendship between the respective personalities of Wheaton and Phoenix, plays an instrumental part in maintaining things interesting even through the rocker parts of the narrative.It plays an instrumental part in maintaining stuff interesting even through the rocker parts of the narrative, and it should be noted that the film boasts an increasingly fascinating feeling as it passes into its tense and amazingly touching third act - which efficiently cement Stand By Me's location as a timeless coming-of-age drama.

review_title: This is why I don't trust ratings anymore

review_detailed_main:
There are no words for me to express my complete and utter love and admiration for this movie and the actors in it. Initially my friend and I were simply looking for a movie with River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, or Corey Haim.

We weren't attracted to the summary, but ended up absolutely loving the movie to pieces.

I give it a 10, hands-down.

The absolute magnitude and hidden message the movie carries is unbelievable and the soundtrack is to die for.

It is now in a cabinet with only two other movies.

This is one of my favorite movies ever. Rob Reiner does a great job as director. It seems like most kid actors don't have a true connection with the other actors and aren't really being the character. In this movie the kids seem to genuinely feel like good friends that are acting as themselves and really feeling their emotions. I give a great deal of credit to Rob Reiner for that because he really had to help them learn how to act at that age.I was most impressed, however, with River Phoenix who was a fantastic actor, even as a kid. All of the kids are so true to their characters and do an excellent job. I love coming-of-age stories, and this is the best I've ever seen. Not only is it hilarious, but also has a great theme and story. Kiefer Sutherland plays the bully and really does an amazing job at making you hate him. The American 1950's was so well presented and everything that is in the movie really puts the audience in that setting.

review_title: Brought back a lot of memories .
review_detailed_main: It´s Amazing how one movie can make you travel back in time , I was about 22 years old when I first saw the film , but I have not seen any other that captures the motivations and ideas like the ones I had when I was their age . For example I was always intrigued about the fact if Goofy was a dog or what !!!!???? Just Great , a commendation for director Rob Reiner .

Like a lot of movies of this era, it has a lot of heart and personality with a charming sense of whistful nostalgia.

Sadly it drags in places and is hard to watch in one sitting despite the many moments of magic, pathos and humour.

Could have gained from being shorter.

I first watched this film when I was fourteen and have loved it ever since. Something about the pure, raw emotion coming from these young children just radiated into my soul. Stand By Me is a timeless story that can and should be watched by all. From such a wonderful story to a beautiful film adaptation, I would have to say that this is a true work of art. All the actors deliver such genuine character, making the viewer truly relate with everything said. This will always be a movie that I find myself going back to watch, and I hope that those who worked on it can see the vast measure of their efforts.

review_title: A good film about the value of friendship and companionship.
review_detailed_main:
This is one of those films that becomes adorable not only because of what it shows and tells us, but also because of the affective memories it awakens in us, or even because of the messages it brings and which it explains in its narrative. The value of friendships is a more than common theme in cinema, but perhaps this is one of the most paradigmatic and memorable films when the subject is precisely that.

Very consistently based on a book by Stephen King, the plot is simple: four young friends get together to find the corpse of a boy who disappeared, and set off on a long journey on foot that will take them through a series of obstacles and difficulties, and that will test the friendship and unity of the group. The matter itself ends up being quite irrelevant, no one cares about the dead boy. What matters is the journey of the four boys and the way they overcome difficulties, forgetting their differences and what eventually separates them. Each of them has their own sad story: broken homes, families with little structure, domestic violence, dramatic family losses (a father, an older brother...). In short, none of them is a boy born with a silver spoon or into a well-positioned family. And the film explores this very well, with inspired dialogue and absolutely believable and well-conceived situations.

Rob Reiner is a very effective director who knows very well what he wants. One of the points in which he shined most was in choosing the filming locations, designing the sets and reconstituting the period (the film takes place in the late 1950s, at the height of the post-war "American dream"): the director It really manages to transport us to the past and to magnificently designed and credible places. Another point he valued was the choice of actors for the four main characters. In addition to being a perfect fit in terms of age and physique, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell, River Phoenix and Wil Wheaton are very talented and do their best with their characters and their material. Without the effort of these four young people, the film would not have the strength it has.

On a technical level, the film stands out for its good cinematography, the sets, costumes and props that I mentioned above, the choice of period cars and an excellent soundtrack, featuring some iconic melodies of the time.
A short film, with charismatic characters and moving moments.

review_title: Lacks The Character Development Of King's Novella
review_detailed_main:
In the novella "The Body" written by Stephen King that this film is based upon, a group of boys set out to find a local dead body, and end up finding more out about themselves than anything. Along the way, master wordsmith King is able to develop each and every character to a point where readers can really care for or sympathize with their problems or successes.

In this film version, "Stand By Me", though, that incredible character development is lacking. I realize I am a bit "tainted", as I know what I was missing, but suffice it to say that after the novella experience, the film just seemed to lack that extra "oomph" to turn it into any sort of classic.

Of course, I probably am expecting the impossible in this situation, as director Rob Reiner likely did everything he could to develop four very different young men in the span of only 88 minutes, but just that limitation alone drags the story down a bit. Whereas King (as he is known to do) can, in a very in-depth fashion, probe the personal lives of each of his characters, Reiner is restricted to a series of flashbacks that just don't have the same emotional connection with the viewer as King does with the reader.

Now, don't get me wrong...I don't think that this is a bad film by any stretch of the word. If you have not read the novella, I think you might be inclined to give it another star in the rating column (don't expect "classic" status, though). However, if you (like I was) are looking for faces to be put to King's classic characters, locations, and themes, then you will likely be a bit disappointed, as "Stand By Me" fails to carry that mantra like some others have (including "The Shawshank Redemption", a classic movie based on a story in the same collection as "The Body").

This movie sticks with you. It sticks to your bones. If it's the first time watching it you'll forever remember it. I f it's your 10th time watching it's a comforting blanket of nostalgia.

The actors are incredible. One of River Phonenix's best (sadly). His acting skills were so multifaceted for the his age. It makes me long for what could have been. The rest of the perfectly selected actors craft the enthralling tale completely nailing each of their unique characters. They should all get accolades. You feel for each one's story and where they came from. Something that Stephen King was a true master of. Incredible character development.

I'm amazed this adaption of one King's most famous short stories throws me right into the 1960's and I'm ready for the tumultuous ride. Perfect and well done! Kudos to Rob Reiner for bringing King's vision to the screen so we can all see the beautifuly complex story that King wanted to tell.

stand by me is probably one of my all time favorite movies ever its excellent. the story line is brilliant they picked great actors, keifer Sutherland Cory feldman river phoenix who sadly died not long after Jerry O'Connell and will wheaten. they were the perfect second movie i was born in 1996 but this has been

my favorite movie since before i can remember its always been there and always one of the ones i can pull out of my head instantly whenever someone asks my favorite movie its a family movie and i wish i had a child life like this one and friends like these 4 boys i suggest this movie to everyone no matter what age you are.

review_title: greatest movie about every boy's childhood
review_detailed_main:
this is one of my all time favorites. hits me every time i watch it. and i feel like it describes my youth as i share many of the same stories (except for the whole dead body thing of course). it captures what it was like to be a youth and reminds me of what it was like growing up with that close friend or friends. I watched it when i was about 12 or 13 with my best friend and it definitely described us, our closeness and willingness to stick by each other no matter what. We have since lost touch with each other but i still think back often of the many good times we had together and all of the memories we made. back when you spent all summer long hanging out and having sleeping overs at your friends, before you had to worry about getting a summer job and everything else that comes with growing up. This movie makes you remember your youth and it's purity and the gift of close friends.

this quote from the movie just about sums it up: "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?"

review_title: An amazing, realistic and nostalgic experience.
review_detailed_main: I haven't read Stephen King's novel and I wasn't really sure if I was going to like this movie or not. My expectations were high, though. And it turned out to be one of my favorite movies of all time! The first thing that shocks you and leaves you speechless is the maturity of the main actors. Their acting seems to be so real, so down-to-earth and yet fascinating. I am not much of an emotional person and I do not often cry over movies, because there is always an inner voice telling me: This is not real, this is art, it is supposed to be entertainment. But this... It just hit me as hard as it could, I found myself with tears filling my eyes even the day after watching it. I am only 17, and I know that life is ahead of me, but for some reason it just made me feel nostalgic and old. It made me somehow regret watching it, but at the same time I want to watch it over and over again. I am not a movie expert, but for me - this was not a movie. This was my childhood, my memories, my desperate wish to turn back time. And maybe some more competent people criticize particular parts of this movie (for example, the main actors smiled in some scenes even though they were supposed to be serious), but for me these "flaws" made this movie perfect and real. They reminded me of me and my squad when we were that age, our pointless conversations, fights, joking, crying... For me, this movie is by far the best picture of that innocent stage in our lives. And a raw reminder that you'll never be that young and free again. But there are memories that help us. Memories - and things like this movie.

review_title: A film based in the 1950's that's a good coming of age story.
review_detailed_main: It had been many years since I had watched "Stand by Me" and after just seeing it again I realized it had been one of my favorites growing up as a kid. Really it's just fabulous a good coming of age story about growing up as when everyone sees they can relate to their childhood of growing up and being with friends and having fun in the summer all along while dealing with acceptance, uncertainty, and just dealing with the journey of life. Rob Reiner who directed does a fine job adapting from Stephen King's novel that's told by a grown adult who's all grown up played by Richard Dreyfuss who tells about the summer of 1959. And when the film flashes back his youth character is played by Wil Wheaton and it tells of his summer journey with his three friends(River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O' Connell)who set across the Oregon landscape of wilderness and timber to search for a dead body of a boy who's been missing. A good turn is given by Kiefer Sutherland who's tough as the local bully. Overall a film of friendship and most important it's about the coming of age and learning thru the experience and journey of life.

review_title: Books into movies...some times they work some times they don't but Stephen King always works
"Stand by Me" is a classic of 80s, addressing perfectly themes such as friendship, loyalty, personal growth and sense of loss, among others
review_detailed_main:
"It can't possibly be a Stephen King work! ". The exclamation is almost certainly coming from those who watch the movie "Stand by Me, 1986". Adapted from a short story by the author, who through his literary works became known as the master of suspense and the supernatural, The film can cause such astonishment for being classified by the film industry as a drama that addresses themes such as friendship, loyalty, personal growth and sense of loss, among others.

The script adapted by Raynold Gideon and Bruce A. Evans is very efficient, managing to flawlessly convey all the main life lessons of King's book. While the direction of Rob Reiner (from "Question of Honor") is firm, and manages to maintain an electrifying atmosphere, and at the same time, always light and fun, filled with good doses of humor, even in the tense moments that the film provides. The film manages to be touching from its opening scene, when an adult Gordie reads the news in his car about the death of the "famous lawyer" Chris Chambers, his great childhood friend, and gets emotional when he sees two boys riding a bicycle, making a scene. May all your memories of youth come back to you in a stream of consciousness. Does this not happen to us? Sometimes our lives are so full that we forget how good it is to remember the good times of our lives. From then on, we are thrown into the memory of Gordie in his troubled childhood. Even with the almost general lack of perspectives in relation to Gordie and his friends, together, they were happy as no adult is. The film efficiently shows how pure the friendship between the young people is, marked by innocence and sincerity, which everyone knows will one day become extinct. In the same way that childhood friendships are marked, but they are very difficult to cultivate until adulthood. Gordie, Chris, Teddy and Vern, even with completely different personalities, they were souls that complemented each other.

The adventure of going in search of a body not found by the police and the possibility of finding it and becoming heroes, is the representation of any young person's dream of wanting to appear, of being able to do everything. Something like a student with a reputation for being an ass answering a difficult question in the classroom, in front of everyone. Young people feel the need to live each moment of life with emotion, before it's too late. Acting in the way that suits them and thinking that this way they acquire superiority and independence, they feel all the power when invading a forbidden place or simply smoking a cigarette. The film delicately shows all these sensations of being young.

At a certain point in the film, when they are bathing in a river, Teddy begins to play drowning his colleagues. Chris tells him, "Come on Teddy, act your age." Teddy doesn't think twice when he replies, "I'm acting my age. I'm young, and youth only comes once in our lives. We have to take advantage of it". Analyzing this dialogue, we see how much we humans have that "hurry to grow up" and we fail to enjoy great and rare moments in our lives. Looking through today's eyes, we can remember how good youth was, without major responsibilities, and regret that we didn't make better use of those golden years. It is no exaggeration to say that the best moments in each of our lives are when that "child spirit" hits us, making us tell jokes, laugh at our own nonsense or play with that bosom friend of yours.

The film leads us almost like a fifth member of the group, which we get to know more and more along the way. As the plot unfolds, we will realize that life has not been easy for any of them, that they cling as best they can to the final moments of a childhood that seems to no longer want them, at the same time that they begin to perceive the arrival of a world feared adult. It is the strongest metaphor that King presents us with about the fear that comes with the end of childhood. In any film, or literary production that has the purpose of provoking fear, such a feeling is transmitted by external stimuli, such as a murderer, a monster or some supernatural event. In Stand By Me, which I remember again, has a story focused on drama, there is the fear of something inevitable and from which one cannot escape: growing up and accepting life as it is.

Boys perceive this empirically and even if they try to appear strong, they are actually weak and do not know how to deal with such events. The film has moments that exemplify this through each of the characters and their inner fears. Chris is the rebellious young man in the plot, but during a nocturnal conversation with his friend Gordie, he takes off all his masks and cries compulsively, angry at adults and how weak he is in front of one. The same Gordie lives with the weight of his brother's death, who for the family was the favorite son. Claiming that the fear shown by the characters in Stand By Me is the main support pillar of the work would be completely false. It is just one of the elements of the plot, but because it is worked and presented in a poetic, almost playful way, it ends up going unnoticed, diluting itself within the narrative. Mainly because the film masterfully works with noble elements such as the loss of innocence itself, the value of friendship and the importance of moments that mark people.

"Stand By Me" is certainly not an easy movie to watch. Not because we don't feel engaged by the story, but because of the weight of its atmosphere. Although we are dealing with children, their problems mirror those of our unforgiving world and little by little we see how the actions of adults profoundly affect these kids, even molding them into what they can be when they mature. From Gordie's (Wil Wheaton) parents' treatment of him (both before and after his brother's death), to society's prejudice against Chris (River Phoenix), we see boys deeply wounded emotionally, causing not only in tears, as in some behavior not befitting that of a child (although these, too, are certainly present).

Here the title demonstrates all its relevance within the context presented. In this cruel world, these four boys escape reality through their friends - they are the ones they can really count on, as is already made clear in the song by Ben E. King, played both at the beginning and at the end of the projection. This experience is still essential and we see it clearly in the final minutes, when we discover that Chris escaped his "sealed fate" and became a lawyer. You can go wherever you want; Gordie tells him and those words reverberate in the young man's future, leaving us with an outcome that mixes the nostalgia, optimism and sadness of naturalism all at once. Interestingly, the script still works its protagonist, Gordie, as if he were on a true road to overcoming the death of his brother, the only figure who, in fact, knew him within the family. The relationship between the boy and his best friend shows how he leaned on Chris, who genuinely helps him get through this difficult phase. The chemistry between the two is palpable and the melancholy of the author, years later, who writes about his childhood, manages to be perfectly conveyed to us viewers.

Naturally, the choice of casting and, of course, the direction of actors played an essential role here. Rarely do we watch an audiovisual work, with a main cast made up solely of children, that works in such an organic way. We see in them aspects of our own childhoods and the most disconcerting thing is to recognize that many of the problems we face in adult life, they have to face here, evidently in a less mature way and with all that young look at the world - even if the naivety of they have all been shaken countless times. In fact, what we see here is the journey of each one of them towards adulthood.

Rob Reiner's direction still builds the suspense of the script in a suffocating way. A perfect example of this is when they are crossing the bridge on the train tracks. The camera makes a point of showing the altitude they are at and how any slip could lead them to death or a very serious accident, as they need to go over the gaps between the wooden boards. At the same time, we don't know when the train will arrive and whether they will be able to cross in time. The perspective sometimes alternates between large open shots, showing how small they are in relation to the world, sometimes it shows us the look of the protagonist, who constantly checks to see if the smoke from the locomotive appears in the distance, creating in us an anguish that becomes palpable. A similar strategy is used through the parallel montage, which shows us Ace's group (Kiefer Sutherland) approaching the place where the boys are going, showing that we will see a conflict soon, but we don't know what, in fact, will happen . The tension only increases as we witness the madness and even evil of the character, who clearly won't take it easy just because he'll be dealing with twelve-year-olds. This build up slowly leads us to the climax, which is resolved in a way that is both simple and organic yet manages to leave us breathless until its resolution.

In the last scene of "Stand by Me", an adult Gordie concludes his book with a beautiful sentence that sums up the entire essence of the feature: "I never had friends like the ones I had when I was 12. Jesus, but who had?!" As the credits roll to the sound of "Stand By Me" by Ben E. King (John Lennon's version is also beautiful), it's impossible not to feel lighter, and with that desire to be a kid again. When "Stand By Me" ends its flashback, which started in the prologue of the feature, we are truly exhausted, as if we had accompanied these boys on their adventure and in the same way that the protagonist, now older, finds himself thinking about his past, we are left in introspection, our friendships left behind and the extent to which we believe in our ability to go where we want.

Stand By Me simultaneously has very little to it, whilst holding a great depth. The plot itself is simple; four friends early in their adolescence set out on a journey to find a dead body. However, along the way they discover more about themselves than they could have imagined. Or rather, the two main friends discover things about themselves, mainly through reinforcement from those around them.

It's touching to see the strong friendships, but the revelations of their hopes and fears aren't too surprising. It does create greater context, giving a deep background for each of them, which is impressive for a short film, but if any theme is too subtle, or the bond created between the four not apparent enough, the narrator is there to ensure the entire audience understands what the film is driving home.

Every character has a reason for being included, even if they don't generate too much excitement. The acting is good for such young actors, however there is more than a healthy dose of over-acting from Feldman. The basis for the film's popularity is due to it's relatability - everyone has friends or circumstances they can see in the film - yet it's unlikely that later generations will feel such a connection with a world so alien to them.
I didn't like it. I thought it was a bit cheesy and boring. They have a great cast of actors. It was ok.

review_title: The Best Film, The Very Best.
review_detailed_main:
It's just the best film. The very best.

I watched it first when I was 11, in 1989 or 1990, and I thought it was pretty good. I then became 12, and experienced the most profoundly wonderful time of my life, with my 12 year old friends.

I saw Stand By Me again when I was 13 or 14, and it all made sense to me. Ever since, the film has brought out every possible emotion in me, many times over.

When River Phoenix died, I couldn't face watching it for a couple of years. The scene at the end where Chris/River 'disappears' - the thought of it killed me. I returned to it after that, but haven't watched it now for at least 3 years, probably more.

I know virtually every word, but each time I watch it, something new occurs to me. Whoever put the soundtrack together deserves immense credit, it is beyond poignant, beyond beautiful, beyond words.

I often wonder if girls and women are able to appreciate this movie in the same way that boys and men are. I'd be interested in feedback. I have supposed that my intense emotional connection to the characters in this film come from having once been a boy.

I have it on DVD and VHS, but so profound is the effect this film has upon me, I am waiting for the right moment. It is always with me though, and for that I dearly thank the writer (and yes, I've read 'The Body' many times over, but this is a very rare case of film being better than book), the director and the actors, and everyone else involved in making 'Stand By Me' the incredible experience it has been for me, over the course of the last 19 years.

Such a cool movie, you get connected to all the characters fast, and the actors did an amazing job. The casting is perfect. When Gordie is typing on his computer he types "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus Does anyone?" that really hit home for me and i really related to that. The movie shows the four boys (Gordie Lachance, Chris Chambers, Vern Tessio, and Teddy Duchamp) with strong friendships and how important it is to have friendships like the ones shown in this movie. All the boys are going through something in their families, as well as personal lives and when all four of them are together their problems seem to disappear and they are all happier.

review_title: Epic beyond belief for what it is.
review_detailed_main:
"Stand By Me" truly is epic beyond belief for what it is. This is due to various reasons. 1). Its cast is mainly children. Quite often films with casts children dominated lack quality acting as the youngsters simply have just not been in the business long enough to be able to deliver impressive performances. However "Stand By Me"'s young cast all are believable and show great chemistry. River Phoenix in particular is amazing as the brave , yet troubled "Chris". 2). The film is very very short. Quite often the best films are around 2 hours in length. Often this duration is necessary for a film to drum up enough depth for it to stay with the viewer long after the credits. "Stand By Me" has no trouble going into decent amounts of depth and staying with the viewer in only 85 minutes. Its nice to watch a film which doesn't drag on. There is too many of that these days. 3).The focus of this film is on children so you would think it would probably only appeal to a childish audience.Yet it doesn't. It deals with some heavier material than initially expected but this is welcomed by more mature viewers. Plus most of us value our childhoods so its childhood friendship content is refreshing to view as it encourages us to reminisce on our good times of our younger days. In saying that it is epic for what it is I guess it was always going to be in some ways as its written by arguably the most successful writer of the 20th century Stephen King. Richard Dreyfus (Jaws) plays a satisfying side role as the older "Gordie" who narrates the story.

"Stand By Me" is an excellent film. i recommend it to anyone who values childhood, friendship or just wants to witness a fine and ultimately moving piece of cinema. "Suck my fat one you cheap dimestore hood" haha "Sincerly"

SBM is an absolute classic movie. Having read the book "The Body" on which the movie is based as well as seeing the movie both are just fantastic!!!

I love the characters the story, the emotions that they show, it just reminds me of childhood, about the friends you make, about the friends who you lose.

if you haven't seen SBM i recommend that you do.

"The most important things are the hardest to say, because words diminish them" The Body Stephen King

'STAND BY ME' - 1986

Directed by Rob Reiner

Starring Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell

Plot Overview: After learning that a stranger has been accidentally killed near their rural homes, four Oregon boys decide to go see the body. On the way, Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton), Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell), Chris Chambers (River Phoenix) and Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) encounter a mean junk man and a marsh full of leeches, as they also learn more about one another and their very different home lives. Just a lark at first, the boys' adventure evolves into a defining event in their lives.

It's become apparent of late that I've been watching movies based on Stephen King novellas. I've watched Misery, The Green Mile, 2017 It and now I've got to 'Stand By Me'. With the exception of perhaps 'The Shawshank Redemption', 'Stand By Me' is King's most celebrated film and has received plentiful amounts of critical praise. And after seeing it, I think it's okay. 'Stand By Me' is now means a bad movie and by Coming-Of-Age standards, it is pretty great. But I don't think it deserves the mass praise it receives. I still recommend that you see it because it's still a good film but I certainly don't think that it deserves the massive praise that it receives.

As far as pros go, I could name a few. I liked the performances, for a start. Wil Wheaton does a pretty good job as Gordie Lachance, as does his older counterpart Richard Dreyfuss, in narrating the story. Wheaton's peers, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell also do great jobs in bloating out the cast and making the characters come alive.

All the cast who played the bullies in the film also did excellent jobs.

I also really liked the fact that the story was character driven opposed to story driven. This made each of the character's arcs mean something more and elevated the characters from good to great. The actual story itself was pretty basic and could have used some more adjustments but the overall narrative was strong and engaging, thanks to the characters.

Honestly, I have no major flaws with this movie. Everything is at least semi decent but I just didn't enjoy it as much as everyone else did. It's fine but I can't see myself ever watching it again. It was entertaining while it lasted but even now as I am writing this, I am struggling to remember what exactly happened in any logical order. It's an unfortunately forgettable movie and, while I do recommend you see it, I don't really see the critical praise it has received. I'll rate 'Stand By Me' 7 'Dead Bodies' out of 10.

A story about friendship but also about parting ways.

This film really does show the purity and rareness of true friendship. It shows how friends support one another in tough times, each of the kids in this movie all have problems at home so they hang out with each other to take their mind off of things. This movie also shows something that most movies under this genre lack and fail. It shows how sometimes the kids are wiser than the adults, I mean some of the things these kids do and say really tops this movie above all others. The movie symbolises how the friends we make when we're kids will likely be the most fun, trustworthy and remembered friends you'll make in your lifetime.
