review_detailed_main: The minute my mom called me over to watch this movie I knew it would be great. I laughed, cried, and sat on the edge of my seat practically every minute! The way each actor portrayed each part was extraordinary! I was amazed at the talents of each of the young actors. My personal favorite was Chris Chambers, played by the late River Phoenix. His acting was phenomenal! When he broke down and spilled out his emotions I felt his pain. Sometimes my mom will automatically accuse me of things and sometimes my teachers will and they don't even let me have a say in anything. I just get in trouble right away. It was the best adaptation of any Stephen King book I've ever seen. I give it two thumbs up.

Another adaptation of a short novel by horror writer Stephen King, although this time around the original story, The Body is not a scary one but a drama about preteen boys growing up in a small town.

Rob Reiner; formerly well known as meat head on All in the family, does a marvelous directing job turning Kings work into a first rate film depicting the journey of four friends looking for the body of a missing classmate. He was apparently run over by a train.

River Phoenix, Jerry O'Connell, and Corey Feldman play the youngsters and Wil Wheaton is Gordie, the narrator of the story told through flashbacks with Richard Dreyfuss taking over as the adult Gordie.

The four encounter the local bully, Ace(Kiefer Sutherland) and his cronies along the way and they also learn a great deal about each other on their adventurous quest. Stand by me is one of the better Stephen King inspired movies.

review_title: #205?! It should be in the top 10!!!
review_detailed_main: What's not to love about this movie? It is a truly touching film that shows what the friendships of twelve year old boys in the 50s. It shows us what true friendships should be like and what it was like to be twelve in the mid-twentieth century. I have never spoken to anyone ( anyone mature) whose life wasn't majorlly impacted by seeing this film. Even though words can't express the beauty and honesty of this film, I'll try to do my best. It is true that this film is usually appreciated more by adults, but I believe it would be a shame if children didn't see it ( to fully appreciate their childhood and friends). The film is rated R for language, some use of tobacco, and some sexual references ( not too bad). If you are worried about showing it to your children think about this: the film teaches a good lesson about life and friends; that is worth letting them hear a few bad words. I cannot express the impact the movie will have on you personally ( ranges for everyone); but it more than likely will change the way you look at life.

review_title: The closest a film has ever come to being perfect

review_detailed_main:
Well, I have taken the 10 Star reviewer recommendations on board to watch this "unmissable" movie and now that I have watched it I must honestly admit that I am terribly disappointed. Let me clarify. The disappointment was not about the cast or the way they performed their roles. They all performed well what was asked of them. The disappointment was due to the mediocre storyline, which again according to the 10 Star reviewers had some message in it, and that it was a masterful storytelling, and that it is one of the best movies ever made, or even the best movie ever made, an all time classic.

Friendship is a state of enduring affection, esteem, intimacy, and trust between two or more people. Friendship is also a very personal thing and depending on one's own experiences of their early life years friendships, will or will not relate to the movie's storyline accordingly. If you relate to it then it's a no brainer 10. If you do not relate to it, then you'll be left searching for hidden messages whilst considering a 3, or perhaps a 4 Star rating as sufficiently generous. A childhood journey with friends and some juvenile pranks along the way. No poignant message to jump out of the movie and grab one with the intensity that strongly bonded friendships deserve. That's all folks.

review_title: One of the best movies River Phoenix ever made!!!!
review_detailed_main: This movie is a must see!!! Stand By Me is one of my favorite movies! If you like this movie then you will like Now and Then too its just a spin off of Stand By Me. If you like River Phoenix, I think that this was one of the best movies he ever made!!!!!!!!

I love this movie so much, is represent a part of my childhood when I had 3 similar friends with similar adventures before a moved.. is represent all generation before iPhone that why is rated one of the best 250 imdb movies if you disagreed you must had a t3rrible childhood or you're from new generation which make no sense to you.

review_title: A Perfect Trigger and Gateway to Memory Lane
review_detailed_main:
I haven't expected too much from the movie at the very beginning. I thought it was just another 80's generational movie which will not resonate too much with me. I was utterly wrong because Stand By Me proved to be a perfect trigger and gateway to memory lane. It reminded me of the famous madeleine episode in Swann's Way, Marcel Proust's novel. The novel narrator eats madeleines dunked in tea which helps him recall certain past events by triggering his involuntary memory.

The film opens with a sequence where the narrator (Richard Dreyfus) sits in a car shocked by the newspaper title of a lawyer's violent death as two kids pass by his car on bikes. The plot then turns into a childhood story, when the narrator and his friends, went to find a dead boy's body in the woods. One of the friends in the company was the earlier mentioned killed lawyer with whom he had a great relationship as a kid. Moreover, he helped him raise his self-esteem and bring back his confidence on numerous occasions.

I liked the characters in the film because it perfectly depicts boys in every junior high school company. Gordie (Will Wheaton) is a smart but insecure, invisible boy. On the other hand, Chris (River Phoenix) is a rebellious, intelligent kid who has the potential to become good at anything if he could only have a good role model. Teddy Duchamp (Corey Feldman) is an ill-tempered, self-destructive, romantic kid. Finally, Vern (Jerry O'Connell) is that bothering kid who desperately wants to be a part of the group but isn't cool enough for that.

This film was fun to watch since it served as a trigger to remember people, places, activities, and games I played as a child. I was also doing a lot of stuff with kids from my hometown that I don't have any contact with whatsoever. At the time, those kids were my best friends, and numerous great memories were waiting inside of me to get back on the surface again. I love the magic of film that can make such things happen.

review_title: I can see this movie OVER AND OVER AGAIN!
One of the Greatest Films of all time
review_detailed_main: Stand By Me would have to be one of the greatest films of all time.I first saw the film when I was about 8 years old(even though I was meant to be sleeping), and even though I didn't understand most of what they were saying I still found it a great film.I rediscovered the film at the ripe old age of ( I'm not joking)12 going on 13. And soon thereafter elected it to be my favorite film of all time.The acting was of a standard I had never seen before. I mean you could really believe that they were real people, not just characters played by actors. Unbelievably talented ones at that. Stand By Me is the kind of film where you can laugh along with the characters, and cry with them to(and cry I'm sure many of you Stand By Me fans did). The kind of film that, each time you watch, you find something you missed the time before. This film reminds you that life is short, and friendships are much shorter. Most of all this film makes you believe in yourself, even though others may not.

review_title: Stand By Me When You're Not Strong!
review_detailed_main:
Stand By Me Is a beautifully crafted story about the friendship of four young boys on the hunt for a rumoured dead body in the forest. The hunt is on and the movie is very entertaining from start to finish with many known actors including the likes of Corey feldman, Will Wheaton & and the late River Pheonix.

What i love about this movie is the vibe it gives off, it's the type of movie you can start watching and before you know it, its over. It really is a fasinating story that you are bound to enjoy, i know i did and still do. These types of movies are always well thought out, the eighties truly was the year of the best films about.

If you haven't yet dseen this classic i really think you should, it's an entertaining, enjoyanle experience.

Highly recommend!

review_title: The Time That Memories Are Made Of.
More I watch it the more I hate it!

review_detailed_main:
I taped the film some weeks ago & finally got around to watching it. I thought the story line was good; maybe because I could identify the four boys with my own childhood at that age before girls came into the picture. The acting was good although at times I missed the dialog & had to reverse the tape to "catch" what the boys said. My only criticism was that expressions were used that were more contemporary than the 50's, and I find it hard to believe that twelve year old living in the early 50's used so many four lettered words.

In any case, it is a good film; down to earth; excitement particularly the "train scenes" and a picture of North American Life in the 50's. The music was tops!

review_title: Good movie which holds up well
review_detailed_main: I saw this movie when it came out and just re-watched it with my kids a few weeks ago. It held up really well and is a solid watch with some great performances from some young actors. The story is compelling and holds your attention and the soundtrack is great.

review_title: A Stephen King Tale Well Done

review_detailed_main:
An simple story that is delivered perfectly.The four boys acting is brilliant, especially River Phoenix who was the star of the film. All Stephen Kings books are simple and are able to be read by anyone and the films are the same, simple but magnificent.

This is one of those feel good movies that you'll watch on an Sunday evening. Its tells the story of four boys searching for an dead body which is located in an remote area. That all there is to it but thanks to the engaging characters and acting, the film is an joy to watch. It all about the good times of childhood while at times it shows the hard times also.

Overall it an great film. It to hard to pick an memorable scene, there not many that you will remember and love but still, every scene is fun and exciting to watch.

I dont why in the world I am just now seeing this movie. Yes I am just now watching for the first time, 34 years after the movie was released. I was born in 1992 so this film was released just 6 years prior and some how I never came across it? My guess is the language(bc I wasn't allowed to watch things with a lot of violence or cursing) but I sure am glad I got around to it. I love the pace this film has, I love the humor, the emotion and the acting! It sure is a shame about what happened with River Phoenix. He was amazing in this and I could easily see him being highly regarded as an actor today just like his brother is. This picture just hits you right in the feels giving you all kinds of emotion. Great film!

review_title: The definitive movie for describing life through a twelve year olds eyes.
review_detailed_main: I'll always say it, but Stephen King's no-horror stories are consistently far better than his horror. This is a shining example of a great story with a great script, that doesn't have an ounce of traditional horror in it. King knows how to write real people, very well. This will always be one of my favourites, it is lacking in a few places, but it is so succinct in others that you can't really complain. It manages to get a harrowing, enjoyable, simple and beautiful story into 90 mins and is riveting to watch. No other movie has captured the essence of being twelve so well. Forget the Goonies or Home Alone or any of that other stuff, this is a kids movie and an adults movie at the same time. It taps into how you miss being twelve, even when your thirteen! The characters are seen at a time just before they lose all innocence; before women come into there lives and change everything. This is a movie that always brings a smile to your face and can be watched time and time again.

review_title: A slice of life story of four friends in 1959.
Four boys learn about the adult world

review_detailed_main:
There has never been another coming of age movie quite like this one and chances are there will never be.

This movie has it all the best acting, a great plot, great direction and a great soundtrack.

I have seen it at least ten times and am not ashamed to admit it. I first saw it as a twelve year old myself but never gave much thought to it. Then as a 16 year old I saw it again and never has a movie taken me *for a ride* with it ever!!

I cried every one of River`s tears, laughed with every laugh, stood on my toes to push them to run faster. I felt the fear and the joy of being together with people who matter to you most at that age.

It just made me look back to my childhood as a Twelve year old. There is so much in common that it is unbelieveable.

The movie makes you realize that yes life was that great and that much fun and that is exactly how *cool* we were as kids. How we used to laugh in the amazingly similar ways, those memories, the stories, the camp fires all floods back. Its the friendships which are formed when you are 12 and the way you live as a 12 year. Stand By Me makes you feel nostalgic and yes the last monologue...I for one know that I never had friends like the ones I did when I was 12.

If you can come out seeing this movie not laughing, crying and singing with the characters and not feeling any nostalgia at all you missed out on the best times of life!!

I`ll see it again and again...so should everyone.Oh how I wish I could be 12 again!

review_title: One of the greatest movies I think I will ever see,
review_detailed_main:
I love this film. The summer before 7th grade when I was 12 (I'm 13 now) my mom recorded this movie for me while I was at my grandparents house over the summer. I came home and she's like "watch this, it's one of my favorite movies" (she grew up in the 80'). I watched it and I remember trying to figure out the meaning. I watched it a few more times and realized I fell in love with it!

I understood all the characters feelings, about what its like growing up.

I love all the characters and love all the things they go through. It just it makes you feel like your there and gives you this wonderful feeling. I hated it when Ace and his stupid gang would pick on them, and I laughed at all the funny scenes. I loved Teddy's laugh, Vern's scared face, Chris's emotion and Gordie's intelligence. Well, I downloaded it onto my iPod and bought the DVD, so I made sure my friends saw it. Of course they all liked it. Me and my friend Jodi were always "skinin it" and me and my younger friend Meghan still dance to "Lollipop". And for some crazy reason I feel the urge to dodge train near where my dad lives.

I did read the story to get more background on the characters and what happened after they went home, all I can say is Stephen King is the "King" :) Very good in how he describes adolesnce.

I can relate to how Gordie said he never had friends like the ones he did when he was 12. I know that sounds funny since I'm only 13, but I've lost a few friends. My best best friend Jodi moved to the city, and I miss her, we still talk but I doubt if we can ever meet up again. We had some great times together, we did some stupid stuff that got us in trouble but we have memories. My friend Karina is moving next week to the "city", so thats another friend missing from the lunch table.

Friends really do come in and out of your life just like busboys at a restaurant... <3

review_title: One of the all time best coming of age movies
review_detailed_main: This movie stands the test of time and is without doubt one of the best all time coming of age movies. Highly recommend.

This is a beautifully shot, very entertaining movie that everyone should watch at least once. I've given it an 8. It is also a movie which bears absolutely no resemblance to reality on any level. Loads has been said about the wonderful acting (Wheaton's and Sutherland's performances carry the movie), the excellence of the simply told story, the great one-liners, etc, so I declare that this review will focus entirely on what sucks. This is one of the cases where Stephen King, master of the dark side, whose work is sometimes but mostly not outshone by the film adaptions, was more truthful with his version.

Nothing very much happens that has any concrete repercussions in this movie - with one exception. Gordie persuades Chris to work hard at school. Chris does and becomes a successful lawyer. Chris dies wretchedly after being stabbed in a restaurant. The movie needn't have branded Gordie as being 'responsible', the point is not that Gordie murders Chris - the point in the original book is that horrendously tragic things have a habit of happening whatever you do. The failure of Gordie's attempt to save his friend is *the* key event of the book - which is why Vern and Ted die in that version. They don't die in the film (the correct decision), but the filmmakers totally glossed over this aspect. As a result, it doesn't remotely feel like Chris's character has died at the end of the film; we never see, say, a photo in the paper, of what he looked like grown up, and there's no sense of loss, because the movie concerns itself entirely with childhood. It would be easy to get heavy handed with this kind of thing (King, in fact, often, goes OTT in his fiction) but really, the movie treats the whole thing with kid gloves. There's no sense of the real darkness and terror of childhood whatsoever.

There are a couple of technical problems. The actor playing Ted looks too old when he's got his glasses off (he's was 14, Phoenix was 15). More serious is the cop out with the body itself - the body is not that of a child at all, he looks 15 at the youngest. This seriously reduced the emotional impact of that part of the story for me - the book was subtitled "Fall from innocence". If The Body itself looks as much like an adult as an innocent, what kind of falling happens? The deer scene also bugged me because I read the book first - the deer stands about three feet away from him, for God's sake! Wild animals just don't behave like that, and it wasn't necessary for the scene at all. Less important is the one fairly large plot hole: that, as Ace and co have a car, there's no reason why they couldn't just drive back into town and reveal the location of the body, get the glory, etc, long before the boys walk back.

Ultimately, though, this film succeeds in it's mission of appearing to say something deep in as nostalgic a way as possible. Cute children undergoing serious physical and emotional trials is one of the things the cinema was invented to depict (see Night Of The Hunter, E.T., Schindler's List, etc), and Will Wheaton's amazing cuteness is more than up to the job.

This movie combines the best of so many truly gifted artists. It's based on a Steven King short, directed by Rob Reiner and stars 4 perfectly cast and directed young actors. It runs the full gambit of emotion, in no way lessened by the youth of the characters of actors portraying them.

No matter what your youth was like, this movie has some of your past in it. Anger, confusion, coming of age, finding independence, camaraderie with peers, standing up to bullies (or not), misunderstood or abusive parents, and most dramatically, finding the friends who get you through whatever you may face.

And if you have the opportunity, you should definitely view the 'featurette': Walking the Tracks. The interviews with the actors, director and Steven King are as informative and entertaining as any special feature you'll ever watch. Among other things, hearing Rob Reiner talk about how he took 4 very young and completely inexperienced actors and made this movie is a true vision into the art of being the "Actor's Director".

This one should be on everyone's favorite list. A solid 8+.

But that's just my two scents. :)

I'm a 14 yr old girl and i feel like a traitor. I loved "Now and then", the girls version of Stand by me, but i thought Stand by me was so much better! We saw this film at school, and when the class ended, we had only gotten through half of the movie! I couldn't wait till the following week to see the rest! I was so desperate that i watched every clip ever made about the film on the web, and i read most of the reviews.

The characters were so wonderfully acted. Especially River Phoenix, i found the milk-money scene so touching it made me cry...in class!

I recommend this movie to everyone. I love it.

Love this movie to death! It was the first to spark my River Phoenix and Wil Wheaton obsession that was soon to come. But in all, this movie is adorable and all, it's also really touching, it also got very sad and emotional at times. But this movie gives me so much joy. The boys' relationship was amazing and so precious. It reminds me almost of my life. Me and a tight group of 6 other kids of several ages would go out all day and just explore and live it out. I relate a lot to Chris in so many ways. I really felt for him.

Many years ago I saw "Stand By Me" for the first time. Since then I've seen it a few times and it still has more or less the same effect on me.

A group of friends learn about a presumed dead boy who has been missing for several days and was last seen a few miles from their hometown. It doesn't take long or it is decided that this group leaves their homes for the trip of their lives.

The movie isn't so much about finding the body of the deceased kid, it also isn't about the trip. It actually is about friendship, growing up and how friendship and people change during certain events in their lives.

As they continue on their hiking trip, they have to deal with certain personal issues that everyone encounters in their life. By the end of the film, they haven't physically but mentally grown up because of what they experienced together... as friends.

I always have been felt moved by "Stand Be Me" because of what they go trough and their friendship. Because the whole situation is so real, some moments do come over as a bit scary.

The ending of the movie is what's most touching. Both his character and eventually himself later in his life share the same fate. This gives the ending of "Stand By Me" a more powerful and emotional meaning.

Also seeing Richard Dreyfus as the grown up Gordie LaChance with his kids playing outside is powerful: kids grow up and go their own ways often 'forgetting' their friends. Even though this happens, deep inside them the friendship still goes on forever.

For their age, all 4 boys did a superb acting job. I don't think it's easy to find talented actors at that age today.

My score for "Stand By Me" is 9 out of 10. Superb acting, writing, directing, (touching) music, etc. If you haven't seen it, you won't regret if you see it.

I love Stand by me, I could watch this movie all day I love it so much its funny & sad. Wow Late River Phoenix plays Chris so well and he did the milk money part so well River is Amazing actor in the world,I fell in love with river and I was so sad when I heard the news of river death so sad and heart broken, He always in my heart and when I watch end of Stand By Me It was sad when Chris fade away in the air :( that the most Sad part 2 watch :( That what happen 2 Lovely River Phoenix. STAND BY ME My all time Favourite Movies all time, all the cast's are great & funny & cute. I got the DVD & soundtrack , Song stand by me is great song and I love the video with Ben E King and I love when River & Wil Dance with the Singer they having the time of there life They both look so cute.

RIP River Phoenix

Such a tender and warm movie that is hard to not adore. It has such a nostalgic feel, and has that wonderfully carefree vibe. It is a very well done representation of boys that at age, and at that time. Maybe also because it was very well cast. I think everyone should see it at some point in their lives.

I must have seen this movie ten times and each time it gets better. The tale about the lives and adventures of four boys who live through trials and tribulation. I cried with them, laughed with them and felt their fears as my own. That is what this movie becomes...a true experience. Yes I saw it again and I too remembered that not too long ago, I too was like them, a boy with friends who would go to the end of the world, a boy in search of himself. River Phoenix delivers a performance that we have not seen from an actor his age. Truly splendid, leaving one to wonder what he might have achieved only he was still alive. A very poignant ending, where the actor looks back at his life down nostalgia lane and delivers a worldly truth...yes the best friends are those that we had when we were still young, free and looking forward to all the challenges the world may hold...for we were invincible then!!

Its a movie you should watch and once you have you should try and relive that age once again. Its a movie which brings your inner child back. Go swimming through swamps, get bitten by leeches, run on rail tracks, taunt the dogs which chase you and most of all enjoy and relish the true friendships that you have and reconnect the ones you had forgotten about.

I'm 47 and my daughter is 15. We've watched this movie (together and independently) in last 5 five year more than thirty times, that's for sure. From time to time one of us say to each other "Let's watch 'Stand by me'"...it's interesting how we both love this movie. I'm male, she's female, when I was kid I lived in former Yugoslavia, she lives in London...but we both found in this movie these universal human values about life, childhood, growing up, friendship, parents, humor, love etc. Rob Rainer's masterpiece. Beautiful movie. It's already classic.
If you're reading this then you need to watch MORE movies...starting with Stand By Me. Ultimate classic, R. I. P. River Phoenix.

Labor Day Weekend of 1959 for four boys in Castle Rock, OR, would turn out to be the best weekend for them, for as news of a dead teenage boy's body found outside town would turn that into such a weekend that they will never forget.

Based on Steven King's The Body - part of his story collection Different Seasons - Stand by Me (I've watched that movie before in HBO several times) is one of the best coming of age films ever made, and one of Rob Reiner's best directed movies ever.

Told first hand by one of the boys years after that weekend, this movie is a tale of friendship and growing up that everyone should like.

Staring Wil Wheaton as Gordie Lachance (and later more famous in his 3-year stint in Star Trek:The Next Generation as Wesley Crusher), the (sadly) late River Phoenix as Chris Chambers, Corey Feldman (one of the Goonies) as Teddy Duchamp and Jerry O'Connell as Vern Tessio with John Cusack and Kiefer Sutherland in other roles plus Richard Dreyfuss serving as the narrator (and the adult Gordie), this was one of the best hit movies (and teenage movies for that matter) that made 1986 one of the best. What a great adaptation it was of a Steven King work and BTW Different Seasons was the source book for two more successful adaptations of King's works in film: The Shawshank Redemption and Apt Pupil.

The finale somewhat mirrors what happened to the four lead actors after the movie was made, but we all know that friendships truly last forever indeed and we can always remember what it was like to had one.

To paraphrase Dreyfuss's final line: I had so many great friends when I was 12 and preparing to graduate from my school in Makati in the Philippines that I will always truly remember. Jesus, does anyone?
The writing, the variety of characters, the issues they handle and the range of kinds of comedy is all on point. You are missing out if you haven't seen this.

review_title: Go check out the new DVD right now!!!
review_detailed_main:
Just did so myself. If you haven't seen the movie, you're in for a real treat, a truly wonderful movie.

If you HAVE seen the movie, you can enjoy watching it again, of course, and re-live the days by hearing the principals talk of their memories of making the movie. Some surprises, at least for me, include:

Rob Reiner and Richard Dreyfuss were friends back when they weren't much older than the kids in this movie.

Jerry O'Connell was scared to death of Kiefer Sutherland, which was probably on purpose, as Jerry's character was supposed to fear Kiefer's.

It was touching to hear the guys talk about River Phoenix, and amazing seeing him alive again in the music video, hamming it up with Wil Wheaton and Ben King.

In other words, I enjoyed this very much!!

review_title: one of the best i have ever seen.
review_detailed_main: i absolutely love this movie. it really does show u the rights of passage u have to go through to be recognized as an adult.the entire cast is great throughout the movie, not to mention they are all really cute.my favorite would have to be Wil Wheaton(Gordie Lachance) because he is a really good actor. if at all, i would recommend this movie to anyone who loves drama and a good cry because there is a lot of that in it.i would also like to say that there is a bit of action in it for the people who love action flicks. over all, the movie is awesome so rent it now people.u may not like it or you may love it but at least u watched it and can now tell people the greatness about it.

review_title: You will never have friends like you had when u were 11
review_detailed_main:
This movie is one of the best movies I have ever seen & perhaps one ever made. You can easily connect with the movie, the characters & incidents that take place in this movie.

Even though it is a cult American childhood movie this will appeal to people all over the world who enjoyed their childhood. I do remember the little adventures we used to have back then in a small town in India with similar friends. We used to hiking in a nearby mountain & I still cant forget those days.

I am not going to comment anything on the plot/story because its such a classic & I might not do justice trying to capture the magic the movie creates in mere words. This movie has left a ever lasting impression on me & takes me back to those golden days each time I watch it(already seen 4 times!!!) This one will always remain as one of my top movies.

review_title: In my real life I WAS "Vern" the shorter, heavier of the main 4 boys in movie
review_detailed_main: This story was based loosely on when Stephen King and I were young together ,,,, In real life Stephen was the tallest of the 4 main boys ,,, and I was shorter, heavier Vern who jumped off the bridge ....We were 36 when movie was done ,,, so Corey Feldman played Stephen and Jerry O'Connell played my part ... At the end of the movie, it said that we would meet in the Seventh Grade ,,, and that is the first year we had Elementary School together ..... For six years of schooling we had over 1100 lunches together and every class except Driver's ED and one other ,,,, He was a great friend although I never saw him over-emotional like in the movie ... the stories I could tell ,,, In the movie Richard Dreyfus did a wonderful job narrating the story,,,sounded just like Stephen //// The movie is wonderful ,, with nostalgic tones all over it, especially the music ,,, The description of Jim was correct at the end ,, he was an attorney who passed away about 40 ,,, but I never drove forklift and left Maine to go to College at a wonderful Christian College near Chicago (notice I never said a bad word in Movie?) I write too ,, but Bible projects ,,,I have a nice mansion upstairs and 500 years from now they will still be reading my books...
This is one great story of friendship and growing up with some big staff for kids movie

review_title: There has never been a movie better.

review_detailed_main:
Well, after so many other comments, there is nothing much I can add. I can only stress to you what a beautiful movie this is.

None of the child actors match the performances that these children put out. Watch this movie!

review_title: One of my favorite movies of all time.
It's a perfect instance of how Stephen King can write something other than horror.
review_detailed_main: Stand by Me (1986) This is coming-of-age drama film that tells the story of four boys in a small town in Oregon who go on a hike to find the dead body of a missing child. It is based on Stephen King's novella The Body. It stars Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell. Each has had a decent career following this movie. Unfortunately, Phoenix died at a young age. He was a genuine talent. This was one of my favorite movies when I was a child. I still watch it here and there, when the mood hits, or the internet is down. It's definitely one to have a copy lying about. The chemistry of the characters engross you into a story of friendship, the kind you miss over the years. These boys are on that cusp of being a child, and becoming a teenager. I possessed the luxury of seeing this as a child, so I will always relate. I strongly suggest this film for parents of children at that age. But it's not just for them. Adults will love this movie too. It's a perfect instance of how Stephen King can write something other than horror.

Based on the Stephen King novel "The Body," "Stand By Me" is a good (albeit overrated) film about friendship.

It's really made all the more touching due to the passing of River Phoenix in the early '90s, which ties in to the plot in a number of eerie ways.

The film is strong in terms of acting, writing and even directing (by Rob Reiner) - unfortunately its flaws are that it's sometimes a bit too emotionally controlling and constrictive, laying on the cheese a bit heavy.

But it is a fine film, worth watching now and again, "The Goonies" for adults.

On another note, I just purchased the new Deluxe Edition DVD, which is really just the old Special Edition DVD re-packaged with a CD soundtrack. The "Deluxe" DVD itself was a disappointment as it even had glaring grammatical errors on the back cover. I felt a bit ripped off.

review_title: Emotional, Poignant Tale About Growing Up!
review_detailed_main:
Rob Reiner's Stand by Me is a wonderful, inspiring coming-of-age drama. Do not expect this film to be like a Disney film as it truly earns its R-rating. But you know, Reiner captures the essence of the teenage spirit. Humans, especially teens, curse all the time. Thankfully, Raynold Gideon's screenplay is incredibly realistic when it comes to depicting teenage friends with different personalities. I cried, I laughed, and I embraced the film. Although I was not yet born when the film was released, nostalgia hit me like a train. I was reminded of my own childhood and in particular could relate to the movie's main character, Gordie.

The film was adapted from Stephen King's novella "The Body." The film's title was changed because it felt like the name of a raucous comedy or a horror film from King himself. Rob Reiner came up with the title and it stuck. King himself believed this is the first work of his that was adapted to the screen the right way. Everyone knows the debacle that was Stanley Kubrick's The Shining. Luckily, King fell in love with movie and he cried. Very high praise! The film was almost cut from production. Adrian Lyne was set to direct, but he wanted to take a vacation, so he was unavailable. Once Reiner took over, the film rights were sold to Columbia. It only wasn't until the film was screened for the head's daughters that he finally decided to produce the film.

Even though the book focused on four teens, Reiner made the decision to center his focus on Gordie, the quiet and sensitive kid who feels uncomfortable in his own skin. The movie then details his experiences with his three friends. Gordie was instantly relatable for me. I was that kind of kid growing up. I loved going on outdoor adventures with my buddies, and we would go on similar quests. Ah, this movie made me look back so fondly on these memories of mine. Reiner said he felt like Gordie too especially growing up in the shadow of his more famous father, Carl Reiner. Reiner previously directed the sweet comedy The Sure Thing, but he truly embraces his own spirit in this feature.

Gordie Lechance (Richard Dreyfuss) is a successful writer. One day while reading the newspaper, he stumbles upon a story about the death of one of his dear friends. The audience then takes a trip down memory lane as he remembers the adventures that his younger self (Wil Wheaton), Chris (River Phoenix), Teddy (Corey Feldman), and Vern (Jerry O'Connell) took in the summer of 1959. The children hear of a body hidden in some Oregon woods, so they try to find the body so they can be heroes. The main bully, Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland) also has plans to find the body and will try to stop the children. As they go on their adventures, they will learn and develop some important lessons about friendship and life in general.

When choosing the cast, Reiner wanted to find actors that closely resemble their characters and he succeeded especially considering the body of work they produced over the years. Wheaton with his nerdy sensitivity, Phoenix with his cool, tough persona, O'Connell with his humor, and Feldman with his withdrawn, emotional attitude. The four actors were great and the chemistry they exhibited is realistic. You got the feeling that they were actually friends. Sutherland made a terrifying antagonist especially with his knife skills. As for cameos or mini roles, keep your eyes peeled for Richard Dreyfuss and John Cusack as Gordie's older brother.

Did you know that this movie revived interest in Ben E. King's hit 1961 song, "Stand by Me?" It certainly did. The songs chosen fit the atmosphere and nostalgia factor very hard. If you want a proper coming-of-age tale that has not been watered down, this is it. Cussing and violence are shown throughout, but isn't that just part of the realistic way of growing up? At least for us normal kids? This film showed Reiner's growth as a director as he came into his own. Stand by Me is a film that is poignant, inspiring, and should be seen by all generations.

My Grade: A

review_title: Rob Reiner & Stephen King - Quite possibly the best partnership in Hollywood history
review_detailed_main: What a great movie. I saw it when it first came out when I was 8. I'm now 22 and have seen it a dozen times since. It gets better every time. The casting is brilliant. Kiefer Sutherland is the best villain as Ace. The music, characters, and props give it that eerie 50s feel reminiscent of Christine, but it also has the wonderful emotional undertones supplied by Rob Reiner. All four kids did a great job. My hat's off to everyone involved. A masterpiece. 10/10.

The thing about Stand By Me is no matter how many times you watch it you still appreciate that you are watching one of the true greats. We are catapulted back to the summer of 1959 where four twelve year old boys take a trek through the Oregon back country in search of the dead body of a missing boy. The four leads have never been better and there is great support from Kiefer Sutherland. The scene where William Bronder quietens and turns the tables on the four rebellious youths by telling Corey Feldman what he thinks of his father is a scream and the best scene in the film. A modern classic.

review_title: Phoenix and Wheaton make this movie
review_detailed_main: A true classic, Stand By Me, delivers on the feels and a few good laughs. Phoenix and Wheaton steal the show with their adolescent friendship and chemistry. The storyline is interesting and unexpected. Surprisingly for a cast of mostly kid/teen actors, the characters are incredibly well acted.

review_title: A thoroughly unforgettable coming of age film
review_detailed_main:
This film, based on the novel 'The Body' by Stephen King, one of the astounding authors of our generation; comes a mesmerizing story of growing up and the emotional dilemmas in the lives of youths. Directed by Rob Reiner, this film tells the story of four 12-year old boys living in a tranquil town of Castle Rock, Oregon in the late 50s: Gordie Lachance (played by Wil Wheaton), a sensitive kid who faces disillusion by his father after the death of his older brother Denny and thus, feels lonely at home; Chris Chambers (played by River Phoenix), a tough, but peace-loving boy who is labeled by many as a bad kid after he was caught stealing milk money at school, and is plagued by guilt after since the incident; Teddy Duchamp (played by Corey Feldman), a flamboyant young man with abusive, war veteran father who once held his son's ear to the stove, requiring him to wear an ear piece; and Vern Tessio (played by Jerry O'Connell), a down-to-earth and overly cautious kid who also deals with a rude older brother. These preteens spend their summer in a tree house playing cards, smoking, and telling tall tales, until they hear the news about a dead kid their age gone missing after being hit by a train. So the four boys set out on a quest in search of him with nothing standing their way but a gang of older kids lead by bully Ace Merrill (played by Kiefer Sutherland). This story told is from narration by an older age Gordie (played by Richard Dreyfuss).

Rarely have I seen a coming-of-age film so powerful and moving as this one. This is a rare film that dives deeply into the quandaries of growing up as a young teen, and director Rob Reiner does this exceptionally well, as do the writers. The film presents us with a story of four young teens who go on an adventure, and learn more about themselves than they ever imagine, and as story goes, we watch as witness how the lives of these kids change and how they learn the true meaning of friendship. These characters develop so well throughout the picture, and the performances these actors are so touching; it is incredibly difficult not to care for these characters. When the film hits its emotional spots, you can just about feel the emotions the characters are facing, especially, for an example, in the scene when Gordie and Chris have a gut wrenching discussion about the hatred Chris deals with after an incident school. This is such an rewarding achievement done by Rob Reiner. There are some parts that will make you laugh, then there are some parts that can have you choked up, maybe even shed some tears. Yes, as this is Rated R, the characters do use some swearing and smoke in scenes here and there, but the film presents this in a subtle way to where it is not exploitative or gratuitous.

Stand By Me is a riveting coming of age film I may never forget, and probably one of the most memorable coming of age films its decade. Rob Reiner did a tremendous job with the film as well as the cast who put on mesmerizing performances. This is also a film that is quite realistic that many teens could relate to in ways. If you haven't seen this film, please watch this.

"The Princess Bride" and "Misery" are certainly great films, and you've probably heard of "When Harry Met Sally..." and "This Is Spinal Tap", but this film right here is Rob Reiner's most exceptional. What makes this film so moving is that the audience can empathize so well with its characters, characters who feels so real because of the challenges they are facing at such a young age. We can relate to the characters because most of us have gone through some similarities growing up.

Challenges such as lacking self-worth, being raised in a hostile family, and society's negative viewpoint of who you are are some of the few that are portrayed in this film. Another interesting theme I found within the film is that, yes, human beings and friends come in and out of our lives without warning, but that's the way life goes. We can share amazing, incredible moments with them, and ultimately those moments just became memories. The four friends in the movie go out to find a missing boy's body, but ultimately find so much more - their self-worth.

Rob Reiner's incredible direction and the performances of the four friends make you feel that the trauma and turbulence in their respective lives is real. A truly wonderful movie this is and should be applauded always, truly remarkable.

Stand by me is about four kids who set off to look for a dead body of a missing kid.

Stand by me is an adaption of the Steven King novel The Body. When I rented the DVD I loved the film and it still hasn't lost its magic. The amount of times I laughed I lost count but the story Gordie was telling them was one of the funniest moments and so was when they were trying to cross the train track and Vern is crawling along the way until a train comes. fans of Cory Feldman (Teddy) will love this movie.

Recommended to all drama fans and you obviously won't be disappointed. If you don't like the movie I don't know what to say.

I almost started crying while watching it, that's how overwhelming this movie was. It brought back so many good memories from my childhood and reminded me how amazing it felt to be so careless and enjoy what seemed all the time in the world during summer holidays with your best mates.

The movie encompasses friendship, childhood innocence, emotions and reminds you what it means to be on a childhood adventure.

review_title: "Quatre garçons in the wind!" Four cool and lovable boys!
review_detailed_main: Who else will read up to this? I have tried to read many users comments but there is only so much time in one day even though it is very interesting. So here I read a few entries and got up to the 14 year old who amazed me by his insight! At 63, I don't think I really grew up from that age, with the same questions and anxieties, Although I don't remember being so brave. But the portraying is so powerful and probably will transport most of the audience. I have been to boarding school and military service and could associate many situations encountered in this story. At times it was a little too much for me. I'm not sure I was using this kind of language at home with my friend. But this days it's fashionable to avoid to sound like "brady bunch" member. None the less I adore this film MM

Okay, I can't understand why I haven't written a comment on "Stand by Me" until now, even though I watch it at least once a year. I guess it's difficult to explain why I love this film so much, I've basically grown up with it, I saw it for the first time when I was about ten years old and I have seen it so many times since because it is so good. The story is touching and true and real -- about the kind of friends you have when you are a kid, when those "best friends" are your world. This is without a doubt the best adaptation of a Stephen King story to date (together with The Shawshank Redemption). It's a very engrossing film, very funny, but also very sad. I especially like the two scenes with John Cusack. The four young leads are all brilliant, but ever since I saw it for the first time River Phoenix's performance is the one that has touched me the most. I really don't know how to put my feelings about this film into words so I'll just say: "Stand by Me" is brilliant, if you haven't seen it I feel sorry for you. (9/10)

I first saw stand by me at either at 15 or 16 and i was impressed. I saw it again, and i had missed so much the first time. i long for the days of being 12 again. Doesn't everyone? The movie stand by me is about 4 boys, who were like the cool kids, who take their biggest adventure. THe film is all about the friendship that is shared along the way. Unrtil the very end. There are many hardships that they face through the course of the movie, and how they deal with them. The movie is based on the short story the body, by Stephen king. Though the movie is written by Stephen king, it isn't scary. With an excellent cast, lovable characters, great scenery, whats not to love about stand by me?

review_title: Excellent character study of the tender years of life.
review_detailed_main: You are 12 years old.You know nothing and are curious about everything.You surround yourself with friends who have that same distinction.You are in those tender years,your last years as a child.It's the best time in a person's life,or at least it should be.This is what Stand By Me represents to me personally.It isn't a story about four particular boys.It's a story about all of us and what we go through in those years.This is an excellent story,brilliantly casted and superbly directed by Rob Reiner.Kiefer Sutherland is profoundly convincing as the chief heavy,and perhaps deserved an Oscar nomination if he didn't receive one.Upon watching the film again for the first time in several years,I found that particular scene where River Phoenix's character,Chris Chambers,fades away as he walks off in the distance particularly sad.Little did we know then that this young man,who was perhaps the best young actor of his generation,would do just that only seven years later,dying tragically at the age of 23.The scene now has a profound sadness to it.Stand By Me is one of the best character studies I have ever seen,and an excellent film.

review_title: Brings Me Back To My Childhood...if Only It Was This Much Fun
review_detailed_main:
Stephen King makes a lot of good books and stories that turn into good movies, so I had high hopes for this one. And I was in no way disappointed.

This is the story of 4 kids, on one last adventure before they are forced to grow up and move on with their lives. They all have/had misfortunes in their lives.

There's the protagonist of the group, Gordie Lachance (Wil Wheaton), who is telling the story. Gordie's brother, Denny (John Cusack) had died the year earlier, and Gordie's parents still haven't accepted the loss, making an impact on Gordie.

There is the mean kid with a soft heart, Chris Chambers (River Phoenix). Chris is pushed around by his brother, Eyeball (Bradley Gregg). People assume that because Eyeball is bad, that Chris is automatically bad as well, and Chris gets blamed for things he doesn't do.

There is the "Joker" in the group, Teddy Duchamp. Teddy admires his dad for storming the beaches in Normandy back in WWII. However, Teddy is also plagued by the fact that his dad is in the "looney bin".

Finally, there is the "pushover" of the group, Vern Tessio (Jerry O'Connell). Vern's only misfortune is that his friends don't respect him at all. He is always the butt of the jokes and whatnot.

The story is moderately simple but entertaining enough: Vern is under his porch and he hears his older brother Billy (Casey Siemaszko), and his friend Charlie (Gary Riley) talking about the dead body of Ray Brower, a kid from school. Apparently, he was hit by a train and his body left in the woods. Gordie and his friends hear about this and set off to find it. However, Billy and Charlie tell Ace Merrill, the leader of the group, and Ace wants to find the body before Gordie and his friends do. Its a race between the 2 teams to find the body, Gordie's group walks the railroad tracks and cuts through the woods, while Ace's gang take a car. Along the way, Gordie's gang share memories, go on mini-side adventures, and just be kids for the limited time they still can.

This was a very moving story. The characters the plot, the music, the atmosphere, all authentic and nicely done. If only all childhoods were this interesting. Oh well, one can dream, right? 10/10.

review_title: "Stand By Me" will forever stand the test of time.
review_detailed_main:
The premise of "Stand By Me" is a rather simple one. A group of four tightly-knit friends living in a small Oregon town, circa 1959, set out on foot to find a dead body. What could easily have been a routine Stephen King horror show is instead an often touching and nostalgic story about the purity and innocence of friendship before the teenage years and adulthood sets in and sours the deal. Director Rob Reiner's best film by far, the subject matter will hit close to home to anyone who has ever had close friendships that crumbled before their time, regardless of what you went through together.

It helps that the actors who portray the foursome – Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell and the later River Phoenix – are about as natural as they come and have seemingly strong chemistry with one another. Watching the story pan out, you truly believe these friendships are real, and for such young actors, they manage to handle the tender and emotional moments of this 90 minute film quite well. The most notorious performance is that of Phoenix, whose budding career was tragically cut short when his life met an end eight years later at the hands of a drug overdose. While Phoenix manages to steal the show away from the lead, Wil Wheaton, it must be noted that the ensemble as a whole did an outstanding job. Heck, if Corey Feldman can make you like him in any film, you know an actor and their director have done their jobs right. The film focuses strictly on these four, with minor characters popping in and out of the past and present, and if the cast wasn't so strong, the movie would have easily fallen apart at the seams.

With such a small running time, you'd think that the film is rather shallow, but such is not the case. Although more could have been expanded on (possibly this film's only true flaw), the story flows naturally as you share the ups and the downs with its characters. "Stand By Me" is a true classic in every sense of the word. It's got a significant amount of nostalgia, and it also has a bittersweet edge, both for its downbeat but true to life ending and for anyone who has lost similar bonds in their lives. The last lines of the writer in the film rings truest and sums up the film nicely: "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?"

review_title: Ultimate example of a work gelling together well to become greater than the sum of its excellent parts
review_detailed_main: Oh geez, what is there to say about Stand By Me that hasn't already been said in the last 35 years? It's perfect. Watch it while it's still on Netflix. Maybe it's the "boy-who-grew-up-to-be-a-writer" in me talking, but there was something so human and true about Stand By Me. This movie is the ultimate example of a work gelling together well to become greater than the sum of its excellent parts-pitch-perfect dialogue, a story intimate and personal enough for its setting and stakes, and resonant themes of coming-of-age are all captured so eloquently in the acting, direction, and nostalgic 1959 production design to make an amazing final product where everything works. I also respect this film so deeply for telling a complete, compelling story where every character leaves an impression in just 88 minutes.

review_title: Pain and pleasure of adolescence captured with unerring accuracy.
review_detailed_main:
If you were ever a 12-year old boy, especially around the 1950's or '60's, I don't see how you can help but love this movie. For me I was won over when the four youngsters set off on their adventure to find a dead body and broke into the theme song from the old western, 'Have Gun, Will Travel.'

No other film I've seen has presented the pain and pleasure of adolescence so vividly. Some of the scenes hit such raw emotional nerves that they make you cringe, not with embarrassment, but with recognition. The friendships depicted between the boys are as intense as any they'll ever have in their lives, although they may only last a year or two more. Director Rob Reiner, working from material provided by a master storyteller, Stephen King, has made a truly touching movie, showing us truths that every viewer will feel in the heart and in the soul.

The four young actors at the center of the film (Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell) do a great job of depicting characters that almost everyone can relate to. Kiefer Sutherland is outstanding as a menacing juvenile delinquent who may stir up some nagging memories for anyone who was ever terrorized by a bigger, stronger kid. This is a film Reiner can be proud of and which compares favorably against the very best.
Why can't Hollywood make more movies like this. This movie has almost everything that makes movies great. It's no surprise that it comes from the mind of a genius (Stephen King).

Stand by Me is a 1986 American coming-of-age film directed by Rob Reiner 🚂

It's very good! 😀 I'd recommend it 👍🏼

FOR SOME, IT'S THE LAST REAL TASTE OF INNOCENCE, AND THE FIRST REAL TASTE OF LIFE.

A movie that picks you up and plops you back into the 1950s. It follows the story of four boys who travel across town in search for a young boy's dead body. But the film is about the friends rather than their trip, taking all of us on the journey of what a 12 year old boy's life is like. Beautifully scripted, you feel like you are 12 again, going on an adventure you never really had.
Geez, this movie is good. Capturing the essence of a pre-teen summer so well. The acting of the tweens too is fantastic! I love this movie so much.

review_title: I never had friends again like i did when I was 12..Jesus does anybody...

review_detailed_main: I honestly can't think of a better movie written , maybe Forrest Gump or a few others . Since I was born in 1980, I was enlightened by the hype of 80s movies and saw a ton of these films , in this genre . Stand By Me ranks Top 10 80s movies not a doubt . With a running time no longer than 1 hr 30 minutes , if your learning how to write a screen play . Watch this motion picture .

review_title: Amazing, a must see coming of age film!
It ages like a fine wine.
review_detailed_main: I'm going to keep this short. To the younger audience that haven't seen this movie, you need to. I'm now 34 and a father of three young children. When I was 13 I had three best friends, and we used to watch this movie almost every month , we practically knew the script. But as I age I find myself connecting more with the narration and remembering what it was like to be that age, how wonderful and vibrant life was, how a whole day used to feel like a whole day and not a few hours, Couple this brilliant capture of nostalgia, with wonderful acting from 4 young talented actors, you have a classic, as the closing scenes say, I've never had best friends like I did when I was 12.... Jesus, does anybody?

review_title: An incredibly important and profound story - this movie is a life-altering experience
Stand By Me Stands the Test of Time
review_detailed_main: Still one of the best coming-of-age movies I've even seen. Just finished rewatching it this past weekend. It's been decades since I first viewed it in theaters. I enjoyed it the first time I saw it and I enjoyed it even more this time. Standout performances by River Phoenix and Corey Feldman. Wonderful direction by Rob Reiner. And the Ben E. King version of "Stand By Me" just gets better and better with each passing year, especially the violin solo.

There are rare occasions in film where every single little thing aligns right, and makes for something beautiful- Stand By Me is one of those films. I am far too young to have been from the 1950's growing up, and even far too young to have seen this movie when it was released- so I guess many may wonder why this one resonated with me so much. I grew up largely afraid, alone, friends came and go and for a little while there I had a small group of close friends I really enjoyed spending time with. We all ended up at different schools, in different lives, with very different opinions, and many different preferences. There probably won't be a time where we all stand in the same room again, but I have those memories- and nothing has ever captured that bittersweet feeling more than this movie. People, especially adults, never truly realize how lonely it can be being a kid- and its heartbreaking to see that this is the same throughout 3 completely separate generations. Wherever we fall in age, gender, race, or conformity, I think I will look back at this film- and know that at one time we were all just little kids like them- eager and afraid- and maybe, we are all still that way. Even just a little bit.

My Rating: 10/10.

This is not just a family or kids movie. I saw this movie with my best friend and we definitely don't have the same taste in film. We are both 15 but I like MArtin Scorsese and she still likes Disney channel. But we both loved this film. It was funny, sad, and heart-warming. We could identify with all the characters.

I have never before seen such a cast of young talents. Even though this is Gordy's story, (played perfectly by Wil Wheaton) the real scene stealer is River Phoenix. He portrayed his characters pain and difficulty by his eyes and the way he delivered his lines. It was clear to the audience that he wasn't a bad boy but just a kid longing for attention. Jerry O'Connell was fabulous as Vern and Corey Feldman delivers possibly the best performance of career.

This movie will make you laugh and cry and re-awaken your heart. Don't miss it!
I returned to this film after 15 years and it is somehow better every time you view it. A true masterpiece

Yes, this movie is definitely sad and you just don't feel the same after watching it. It holds a special place in my heart, especially the unfortunate fact that not only did actor River Phoenix die in the movie, but in real life too! If you've never seen Stand By Me, I highly recommend seeing it uncut instead of watching it on a channel like AMC. Not because of the profanity itself, rather because you need to experience what these boys truly said to each other and how it relates to their emotions so you can fully grasp what the movie's message is all about - how short life really is. I think the saddest line in this movie is when the Writer (Dreyfus) talks about how friends come in and out of your life like "bus-boys in a restaurant". Man, that is very true and very sad to think about. I've been trying to find a best friend I knew when I was 12 and to this day, I cannot locate him. For all I know, he could be deceased. I also used to walk with childhood friends along a railroad track near my grandmother's house in the summertime, so that part brings back fond memories too. The Stephen King novella Stand By Me is based on is also very emotional and I recommend reading it first to get a taste of what Reiner's film will be. It's unforgettable and timeless. Plus, I guarantee your eyes will leak tears by the end credits.

This film has had a huge impact on my life, and I've enjoyed sharing it with my son.

Fantastic, a must watch!

One of the best Stephen King's adaptations. A film about real childhood friendship and how it is often lost over the years. Moments from childhood are the most memorable and this is well shown in the movie.

review_title: Recommended for children of all ages.
review_detailed_main:
A film about the journey of true friendship, based on a Stephen King novel. Rob Reiner is a master at directing simple but touching little stories. Anyone who has watched The Princess Bride and this movie would agree that the late 80's was Reiner's golden years. Most notable of the names in the cast is that of the late River Phoenix, in one of his first film roles. The story revolves around four 12-year-old boys living in the small town of Castle Rock. They set out to find the corpse of a missing child and in the process build brick by brick a friendship that transcends all kinds of relationships. It makes you look back on the past faces that have come in and out of the pages of your own life. The last line of the film is considerably one of the best lines in the history of cinema. "I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve. Jesus, does anyone?" Recommended for children of all ages.

http://iwascalledclementine.multiply.com/reviews

Here I am at 2am, bored, and what do I do? I rewatch this greatest coming of age masterpiece of a movie. I think about myself as a 12 year old (36 now) and it truly is the best time of ones life and the friends you have, truly are the greatest you'll ever have. This movie hits all levels of emotions like only a Steven King adaptation can. My son has just turned 12 and it is time to introduce him to Stand by me. I can only hope it influences him, as it has influenced me. If you have never watched it you are missing out on amazing child acting, great story telling and a "feel" that has influenced so many.

review_title: "Stand By Me" as childhood's beautiful swan song ...

review_detailed_main:
Stand By Me is movie making at it's finest. It is a highly professional piece of work, with a good sense of pace and atmosphere it makes for perfect entertainment.

Plot In A Paragraph: After the death of a friend, a writer (Richard Dreyfuss) tells the story of how along with three friends he went looking for a dead body when he was twelve.

The likable cast is headed by Will Wheaton, Cory Feldman, Jerry O'Connell and the late River Pheonix, with the strong support from Kiefer Sutherland, John Cusak and Casey Siemaszko.

I can't praise the cast enough of this movie enough here, there is not a weak link among them, especially the four young boys, While Wheaton carries the majority of the movie, Feldman gives one of the best performances of his career and O'Connell gets the majority of the laughs. I hate to say any one of the actors steals the movie as all of the young cast are superb, but Pheonix is the star of the show. he was always reliable, but here he is truly awesome. His death at such a young age was tragic. One can't help but wonder what other wonderful films we may have missed out on. Sutherland is perfectly cast as the bully. And I need to mention Dreyfuss's voice over. His delivery is superb.

The full soundtrack is excellent too, not just the title track, the score is another valuable asset to the movie.

Simply Rob Reiner could not have made a better movie.

review_title: THIS MOVIE SHOULD'VE BEEN NOMINATED FOR MORE THAN ONE OSCAR!!!
review_detailed_main: I love this movie! It is awesome, it's so original and energetic and there is not one dull moment. This movie was only nominated for 1 Oscar: Best Screenplay Adaption. I think: Best Picture, Best Director, Best Actor(Wil Wheaton) and Best Supporting Actor(River Pheonix). Stand By Me is a drama based on a short story by Stephen King. Although there are alot of very humorous scenes(Lard Ass story, the comb, the conversations around the campfire) there is alot of depth and meaning. The moral of this movie is: You have many friends along the way but none as memorable as when you were a child. Stand By Me is about 4 boys in a small town Oregon called Castle Rock. There's sensitive Gordon, misunderstood Chris, rambunxious Teddy, and scaredy-cat Vern. On the last days of summer the 4 boys go out and search for the body of a missing kid. Along the way the discover about life and each other. There aren't enough stars to rate this movie!

This is a touching film where four friends go on a journey through the woods and countryside to find the body of a missing boy. Throughout the journey, they learn more about themselves, dealing with adversities and friendship.

Set in 1959, this film gives off a wistful and nostalgic atmosphere of the good old and bygone days. Even if the four friends' goal is to locate a missing body, something that is no less ghastly, the plot's centering around the friends' bond and life challenges gives off a taste of innocence and courage. Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Connell all did an excellent job portraying the four friends, showing off their young-at-heart vibes but also showing that they're mature enough to face down life's adversities, from dealing with their dysfunctional families to standing up to a gang of punks headed up by a young Kiefer Sutherland.

In watching this film, you will feel sentimental, yet optimistic, and you will also feel a sense of adventure and humor where appropriate.

Great cinematography from Thomas Del Ruth, capturing a nice 1950's aura, and great direction by Rob Reiner, keeping the plot engaging and well-paced. This film really reminds you of the sadly bygone days of America's innocence, but also offers a ray of hope for the future generations. From the film's title to the song of the same name sung during the ending credits, this adds onto the very heartfelt drama this film offers and is a movie that one should see.

Grade A

review_title: "Stand by me" gets you go to the past

review_detailed_main: This movie is amazing for many reasons that are apparent and others which are not.I've never heard so many people say that they loved it when they first saw and no how many years since then that they still do. This movies captures childhood, and those last moments before people expect you to act mature. The one last adventure, and on that adventure, they discovered more about each other and themselves than they could have in a lifetime. With a movie like this, It could've been terrible or awesome, and it wasn't terrible. It light hearted, funny and serious all at the same time, which normally spells out disaster. But it's a story thats so easy to relate to. It's a universal thing, but it's still its own. I cried during this movie, and this movie will stand the test of time, just like it has all this time.

This film has its own pace and the greatness of this film lies in the fact that it has one of the simplest plots yet the story telling is magical.

Its about 4 close friends Chris, Vern, Teddy and Gordie who adventure out one day for an event they considered very important and life changing for themselves. During this adventure there are quite a few priceless moments that they share but few of them are pure GOLD like the camp-fire scene.

It also has a great scene towards the end between young Gordie and Chris, which I absolutely loved. That brings me to the brotherhood Chris and Gordie shared, special mention of River Pheonix here, he played Chris and was truly amazing. Chris' character was the best according to me and the special relationship he shared with Gordie is very pleasing and heart melting to see. Almost everyone had friends like these when they were young {may not be exactly 12 years old} BUT thats not the point, We all had our special few before adulthood. Those days were really something else...All the irrelevant things now were very important then. Life was full of fun and carelessness.

One point that instantly put this film on my favourites list is its ending. There are usually two kinds of ends to a film, one the satisfying/predictable and the other is shocking/unexpected. But this film has what I call the perfect ending. The last monologue was so true that I was amazed at its truth value...You will understand what I'm talking about once you see it {I don't want to spoil it for you}. Quite astonishing end and one I'll remember for a long time.

Great, and a classic coming of age film that everyone will enjoy. If it had not shown young characters smoking I would've given it 10. But that doesn't take anything away from the film, its just that I didn't enjoy watching them smoke {I hate people who smoke...I know they probably faked it but the scene was not required IMO}.

I give this a 9.2/10

Everybody should watch this amazing film at least once in his/her life. This film is not only for boys, it's also for girls too. It's about friendship. It's those memories of childhood that we will remember till our death.

review_title: A wonderful film with great acting.
review_detailed_main: I thought Stand by Me was a little depressing. But I still love this great film and it really had an impact on me. It was sad what happened to Chris and I really felt for Gordie (as an adult). A friend like Chris would be very hard to find. Overall, this film shines with some magnificent direction and performances and the script is impactful! Phoenix and Wheaton are great and have full potential. Better than "Now and Then" (which was great also) which followed ten years later!

Stand By Me is a very intense, bittersweet film that I could almost feel the actors emotions - I cried as a teen watching this film. It's not without some comedy thrown in to break up the drama.

The story is well scripted and acted out - so much so you are drawn into the movie with the group of adventurous boys. The movie helps to capture what friendship and being young is all about. Laughter, guilt, sadness, anger, pain, heartache and joy are just some of the emotions this group of young boys went through!

I would highly recommend this film to those who have not seen it yet - particular to those who are coming of age.

9/10

review_title: A great film about kids growing into manhood.
review_detailed_main:
Stand By Me is one of the greatest films ever done.This movie does really show the true meaning of friendship.The cast is great and the directing is awesome.

Wil Wheaton(Star Trek The Next Generation)as Gordon"Gordie"Lachance,Corey Feldmen(The Goonies,Friday The 13th The Final Chapter,and License To Drive)as Teddy Duchamp,Jerry O'Connell(Sliders,Kangaroo Jack,and Scream 2)as Vern Tessio,Kiefer Sutherland(24,Young Guns I and II)as Ace Merrill,Bradley Gregg(Class Of 1999 and A Nightmare On Elm Street 3)as Eyeball Chambers,River Phoenix(Sneakers,Indiana Jones And the Last Crusade and Running On Empty)as Chris Chambers,Gary Riley(Summer School and Botherhood Of Justice)as Charlie Hogan,Casey Siemaszko(Young Guns,3 O'Clock High and Of Mice And Men) as Billy Tessio,Richard Dreyfuss(Jaws)as the adult Gordie Lachance,and John Cusack(Better Off Dead,One Crazy Summer and Con Air)as Dennis Lachance make up this great cast of this awesome movie.

The movie starts out in 1985 as Gordie looking at a newspaper article about Chris Chambers dying in a restaurant stabbing.Gordie talks about his experience back in the Summer of 1959 in a small Oregon town called Castle Rock,when they went to look for the body of Ray Brower.Gordie,Teddy,Chris and Vern go out to look for the body of Ray Brower,a class mate of their's who got hit by a train.Along their journey,they learn more about themselves and learn about friendship.Gordie is uncertain about his future,he has parents who ignore him,the only one in his family who cared about him was his older brother Dennis,who was killed in a jeep accident a couple of months ago.Teddy Duchamp has a deformed ear cause his father had fits of rage and onetime put Teddy's ear up to a stove and nearly burned it off.Vern,who is easily scared,found out where the body of Ray Brower is cause of being underneath the porch looking for his jar of pennies,overheard his older brother Billy and his friend,Charlie,mentioning discovering the body cause of them boosting a car and driving it out to the area.Chris,who came from a bad family,stole milk money from school,has done some bad things,but he helps Gordie out by being a great friend in encouraging him to use his writing talents,put them into good use,not wasting his talents by hanging with his friends all the time.The kids find Ray Brower's body and deal with Ace Merrill's gang.Gordie decides to make a call to the police,he believed that that would be a better way of being a hero.

This movie has a great message in it.I remember seeing it back in 1986,when it came out.Stand By Me has some sad moments and funny moments too.Rob Reiner(All In The Family)did a great job directing this film,his leadership helped shaped the young actors in this film into greater actors.I have the Special Eddition on DVD,the extras are super,the interviews are great to watch and to learn from.

The other cast for this film that are great is Marshall Bell(Total Recall,G VS E,and Twins)as Gordie's father,Frances Lee McCain(Gremlins,Footloose,and Scream)as Gordie's mother,Bruce Kirby as Quidacioluo,William Bonder as Milo Pressman,the junk yard owner and owner of Chopper,a dog who is a big legend in the town of Castle Rock.

I give this film 2 thumbs up and a 10/10.

After the death of one of his friends writer Gordie Lachance (Dreyfuss) recalls an unforgettable summer 26 years ago that involved finding a dead kid. Set in 1959 the story follows four 12 -year old boys Gordie Lachance (Wheaton) , Chris Chambers (Phoenix), Teddy Duchamp (Feldman) and Vern Tessio (O'Connell). They set out on a crazy adventure to find the body of Ray Brower (Luttrell) , four months ago Gordie's brother Denny (Cusack) died in a terrible car accident and this makes Gordie want to find that kid more than anything. What the boys don't know is that a gang of local bad boys including Ace (Sutherland) are also hot on the trail. Now it's a question to see which group will find Ray Brower first. Stand By Me is one of the most poignant films of the 1980's and still remains a favorite today. This film shows how important it is to be there for each other through good times and bad times. 9/10 Stars

"In a small woodsy Oregon town, a group of friends - sensitive Gordie (Wil Wheaton), tough guy Chris (River Phoenix), flamboyant Teddy (Corey Feldman), and scaredy-cat Vern (Jerry O'Connell) - are in search of a missing teenager's body. Wanting to be heroes in each other's, and their hometown's eyes, they set out on an unforgettable two-day trek that turns into an odyssey of self-discovery. They sneak smokes, tell tall tales, cuss 'cause it's cool, and band together when the going gets tough.

"When they encounter the town's knife-wielding hoods, who are also after the body, the boys discover a strength they never knew they had. 'Stand By Me' is a rare and special film about friendship and the indelible experiences of growing up. Filled with humor and suspense, it is based on the novella 'The Body' by Stephen King," according to the DVD sleeve description. The adaptation, by Raynold Gideon and Bruce A. Evans, is one of the best treatments of an original Stephen King story.

Twelve-year-old kids from the 1950s were a lot more mature than I could imagine

Nevertheless, Rob Reiner orchestrates the film beautifully, recapturing feelings that die when puberty begins taking its toll. The four lads from the fifties are played by four young actors from the eighties, but the attitudes and feelings are timeless. This isn't a horror film, but it is all about death dead cars in a junkyard, death-threatening trains, leeches in a swamp, the dead body at the end of the boys' quest... The protagonist's dead brother haunts the film. And, most of all, "Stand by Me" wistfully recalls the death of childhood.

********* Stand by Me (8/8/86) Rob Reiner ~ Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell

review_title: This time Rob Reiner helms a great Stephen King story.
review_detailed_main:
In 1986 I was 10 years old, and I watched this movie for the first time. I remember thinking that it was cool to see a dead body on the screen, but that was about it. It's now 14 years later, and I have again watched Stand by Me, and I now understand what the movie is saying.
