Intensely narrated by Richard Dreyfuss, Stand by Me is a coming of age story for 4 adolescents at the end of their summer vacation before starting junior high school. A very young Jerry O'Connell (Joe's Apartment & Varsity Blues) plays Vern Tessio, the nerdy fat kid that every group of friends has. River Phoenix (Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade & Sneakers) plays Chris Chambers, the `leader' of the group who has many problems with his father and is always looking for something adventurous to do. Teddy Duchamp, played vividly by Corey Feldman (Dream a Little Dream & License to Drive), has his own problems with his father, whom tried to burn his ear off for drinking bleach under the kitchen sink. This group of misfits is all bound together by the smartest of the group Gordie Lachance. Wil Wheaton (Star Trek: The Next Generation), in his first starring role and his first movie in over 2 years, masterfully combines fear, excitement and sorrow in this role. Gordie has just recently lost his brother, whom he really loved, in a jeep accident and his parents seem to have never let go, and tend to ignore him now. Before Frank Darabont got a hold of Stephen King's novel The Green Mile', Rob Reiner was given the chance to bring King's short story The Body' to the big screen. I have never read it, but I do know that Reiner did a fantastic job directing the large body of actors and created a movie experience that should not be missed be any 12 year old, or any adult for that matter.

The movie follows the group of kids as the venture to find the dead body of a boy that has been missing for weeks. Vern hears a tip of where the body is, and tells the others who all agree to spend the next couple of days finding it. Throughout the whole trip it seems the 12 year olds do a great deal of growing up mentally, and begin to realize that they wont be together forever. There are some very funny scenes, the pie-eating contest quickly comes to mind, and the film loaded with some great actors early on in their careers. Some great performances by Keifer Sutherland and John Cusack round out the cast.

The message I received from this movie is that no matter what happens, your friends will always be there for you, and you should never forget them. I hadn't watched this movie in years; and now that I have, I will most certainly add it to my collection.

review_title: Best puberty film to date. A haunting tale of friendship and death
review_detailed_main: I first watched Stand by Me shortly after my father passed away when I was 9 years old. The film tackles the experience of children having to deal with death for the first time of their lives, and naturally I was sucked into the plot and the character's vivid adventures as they stroll between childhood and puberty. Plus, tell me another film where you get the chance to see so many young talents get together before some elevate to stardom and others fade away? Stand by Me includes young Jerry O'Connell (Sliders), Wil Wheaton (Star Trek: The Next Generation), Kiefer Sutherland (24), the late River Phoenix, 80's child star Corey Feldman (Gremlins, The Goonies), as well as Richard Dreyfuss and John Cusack. Director Rob Reiner's assemble cast tells the story of friendship, childhood and death and stays with you long after you finish watching it.

review_title: Stephen King gets all the credit!
review_detailed_main:
Being a fan of Stephen King's novels, it was so important to me to view Stand By Me, a masterpiece both in film and literature. Stephen King is a phenomenal fiction writer and his novels Salem's Lot, It, The Shining, and, of course, Stand By Me, all of them being a film as well, scared the crap out of me while the film I am reviewing now, offered a sense of nostalgia and happiness mixed with a variety of emotions . It has been reported that Stephen King cried after seeing this film because it is the closest adaptation ever to one of his novels and I have to agree to that. Rob Reiner will be remembered as the man who made Stephen King cry and also for making a perfect piece of film making that will be remembered as long as humanity is in existence. The performances from Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell were the best in the whole film and not one of them I mentioned have ever stepped out of line or have made mistakes. The bad actors were Kiefer Sutherland, his bad boy acting was uncool and uncomfortable, and his whole stupid gang. They looked crap and acted sh*t. Pardon my French! The best character in the film was Vern because his humor, appearance, and his stupidity was enough to set the screen on fire. Hot! Hot! Now look at him, all bone and serious! Yuck! To be honest, I was expecting a boring old-fashioned film that would be in the bottom 100 but, boy, was I wrong. I loved it so much that it belongs in my personal top 100. The other lovely thing about this is the nostalgia it offered and it was one of the reasons why this earned a straight ten from me. I was about nine when I watched this and couldn't understand most of it but three years later after watching it again, I loved it! I could go on forever about how good this movie is and that is exactly what I am going to do. So if you hate long comments, dismiss reading this for any further and goodbye.

Four f*cked up kids, who smoke, play poker, talk about pornography and a lot of other things, set out on a adventurous-filled journey after hearing news from a friend about a dead body somewhere outside of Maine. Their journey will be hard and secrets will be out as the foursome go through many hard and dangerous tasks. They think that after finding the body they will be famous and successful but they aren't the only ones who are after the body. A gang of bullies, led by Ace Merrill (Kiefer Sutherland), also find out about the body and it is only a matter of time before one of them reaches it first. And if one of them find it, what will happen next? The story's protagonist is a twelve-year old (I think) kid named Gordie Lachance, whose family is torn apart from his brother unexpected death, and his adventure with friends that changed his lives. His story is important and it sends out a message to everyone: there are no friends like your childhood ones. The film could have not succeed without a bold story like the one in this film. It most certainly would not!

Note: SPOILERS FROM HEREON IN!! There are many exciting scenes that contain humor in this film and all of them are wonderful. I still remember the train scene out of the entire movie because it looked so real yet so funny. Vern trying to crawl across the tracks had me in stitches and his chubbiness made it even funnier and I almost screamed as they were going to get hit by the train but thankfully they jumped . Classic Vern! There was another scene where Gordie tells the bunch a story about Larda$$, a fat-A$$ who wanted to get revenge at a pie eating contest by puking on the audience, and that was a classical scene as well. There were some parts in the film which were somewhat disturbing, for instance, when the group have leaches stuck on their bodies after trying to cross a pond but that wasn't disgusting. A leach stuck on Gordie's balls was the disgusting bit and the blood on his hands made more of an effect. The thing that Stephen King is so good in is making fun of his writing, e.g. Gordie says, "F*ck writing. I don't want to be a writer, it's a stupid waste of time!". The film will be incomplete without the 50's soundtrack that made the film more like the date it is set in. The film didn't even win an Oscar, which it should have, but it is a fantastic film nevertheless and will be enjoyed for generations to come!

P.S. Do Not rent this but buy it because a film like this deserves to be in every DVD collection and if you have viewed this film once, view it again and again and again. Did I leave out a again? Well that was my review, to read more click my name which is highlighted in BLUE.

"Over and Out." 25 January 2010.

review_title: After all these years, Stand By Me has stood the test of time!
review_detailed_main: I first watched this movie with my best friend on August 22, 1986 at the Cortana Mall Cinema in Baton Rouge, LA. Not only was that the day it went into wide release, it also marked my friend's 18th birthday and I suggested watching this after spending some of that day at the Fun Fair Park amusement ride area. So the place was crowded by the time the movie began. There were plenty of laughs during much of the narrative and I remember being touched by some of the more emotional scenes. I don't remember if my friend liked it as much as I did (the only time I even remember him saying anything during the picture was during the scene after Will Wheaton's character shot the gun in the air and when he pointed it at Kiefer Sutherland's bully character, my friend said, "Kill him!"), but he must have still been in a good mood because we went bowling afterwards at Don Carter's. Anyway, I just watched it again at the Perkins Rowe Cinema today-since it's celebrating its 35th anniversary this year, it was only playing at 7:00 this evening-and it's even better than ever! I mean, besides Wheaton, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell, and River Phoenix are aces as the four near-teen boys on their journey to find a dead body who was close to their age. And Kiefer was sure very effective as the bully, wasn't he? And kudos to Rob Reiner for truly understanding what it's like to feel so insecure while growing up with not-so-perfect livelihoods. Stephen King was so touched, he considered this one of the best of films adapted from his work. So, yes, I very highly recommend Stand By Me. P. S. When just watching this right now, I could've swore that one of the bullies surrounding Kiefer was also one of the bullies that surrounded Thomas F. Wilson's Biff Tannen in the first Back to the Future during that movie's '50s sequence. Sure enough, that bully that was in both this and BTTF was one Casey Siemaszko!

This movie is the best adaptation of a Stephen King story ever. It is perfectly cast, wonderfully written and directed brilliantly by Reiner at the top of his game. It shows River Phoenix at his best and only illustrates what a loss he was to the movie business. King is difficult to adapt as a rule because his stories are often based on a supernatural premise which never quite works on film in the way it always works in the books. Stand by Me was a short story (called The Body) in the book Different Seasons, which was my introduction to King and began my love for his writing. It also had Rita Hayworth and The Shawshank Redemption as one of the four excellent stories. Kiefer Sutherland also appears in this terrific movie as does Richard Dreyfuss though their parts are small. As an evocation of kid's lives and relationships it is practically perfect, which is a testament to the writing,acting and direction of this film.

review_title: That movie that everyone should watch.
review_detailed_main: Without a doubt, a masterpiece of cinema. The film had practically everything good, good soundtrack, good actors, an excellent argument, good characters, good bad guys and good morals. The ceilings are also very good and the special effects are incredible. I just did not like the final message while the narrator writes, but even so, it's a fantastic movie. Highly recommend.

review_title: A bit overrated but good, the book was better in my opinion
review_detailed_main: Stand By Me is a film i have seen a few times now.It was based on the Stephen King novella entitled "The Body", which can be found on his novella collection entitled "Different Seasons"(this also includes the novellas which were later made into the movies "Shawshank Redemption" and "Apt Pupil").The film features Wil Wheaton, River Phoenix, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell and Keifer Sutherland.It's a fairly good movie about friendship, but I found it to be a little overrated.It's about these four boys in the 1950's, who go searching for a dead body in the woods during labor day weekend.It's a fairly good film, just not as good as everyone says it is.It's a pretty good movie for kids despite it being Rated R(only for a bit of language and the fact that the kids smoke cigarettes).

review_title: Fall From Innocence-The Body:Stand By Me

review_detailed_main:
It's a timeless coming of age film about a bunch of boys in their early teens on a dumb adventure to find a dead body.

With complex but overall wholesome relationships between them, each struggling with personal issues with parents and what now...

I don't think a movie like that has been done since. Four boys - and they're good friends, with realistic depths to each one, god forbid! In this era of Netflix movies that star boys are illegal after all, apparently.

So this is a gem. Much appreciated, holds up even in 2022. If you're a parent with young boys let them watch movies like this instead of the swill Netflix and Disney produce.

A sweet and heart-warming tale, based on a short story by Stephen King that sets its attention on four boys who venture out into the wilderness to find the body of a "supposedly dead" boy who was near their age. Throughout the movie, I was left with the unexpected feeling that those boys and I had something in common despite the differences in time and generation. Besides, there's nothing wrong with the film in any department and the main strengths of the movie are Rob Reiner's smooth direction and the excellent performances of Wil Wheaton and the late River Phoenix as the ones who serve as the heart/soul and leader of the trio. Well, the narration by Richard Dreyfuss deserves some credit, too. "Stand by Me" is one of those movies that doesn't beg you to pay attention, they ask politely.

This movie was very good. It represented, in an eerie way, the way life was for all of us. It painted a picture of the real world in such a neat way. Using childhood was quite an effective way to portray that hope can always be found despite the circumstances. It allowed the viewer to see that no matter where one is in life, we are all in the same boat together, and sometimes during the hard times in life, that is when the best of friends can be found. I recommend this movie. It is very memorable.

I first hesitated before renting Stand By Me, but I was very suprised! I really liked this movie! It was very good! A great big, wild adventure! Very good piece of film. I really like this movie I reccomend it to adventure fans. Anyone should like this movie! This is a classic! Rent it! I give it a 10 out of 10!!

I first watched this film while i was in class, and was just shocked at how good it is!

I adore this film as i watch it nearly every week, and still enjoy watching it! The characters are amazing and unbelievably excellent. the characters remind me of when i was 12 and how much fun we had.

The music to this film is really good and sticks in your head,just like the characters and their names do!!

So if you havent watched this film, you have to but i bet you wont be able to watch it just once!

Stand By Me is one of the best coming of age movies set in a small American town of the 1950's. The period details are excellent and the story of a band of friends about to enter their teens is very well told. Stand By Me is one of four novellas of Stephen King's Different Seasons. The other two that were filmed were Apt Pupil and The Shawshank Redemption. As I recall, Stand By Me is quite faithful to the original story (The Body) which was very well told. I think the direction and the casting are the real coups that make the film such an endearing classic for many.

Before seeing Stand By Me for the second time after a decade and a half, I got to see River Phoenix again. Any misconception I had that he was an unjustly famous teenage star who was into sex, drugs and partying has been dispelled. Even at the young age of 15 years, he gives a thoroughly assured performance bringing into play a range of emotions. There is no doubt he would have gone far if his career hadn't ended with a fatal drug overdose. The rest of the cast is routinely excellent as well and the humor is very good, albeit shocking to see the extra-curricular activities and language of pre-pubescent boys from the 1950's - smoking and some foul language.

Stand By Me is a very good film for most viewers and I can't understand it being a great film for people who came of age in the 1950's US.

review_title: One of my absolute FAVORITE films ever made...
review_detailed_main: I don't think in all my 14 years that a movie like this has ever touched me so much. I was motivated to see it because I am a huge River Phoenix fan (not those dorky obsessive kind haha) but I got so much more out of it. The acting from these kids was absolutely breathtaking; they each portrayed their characters wonderfully. It was a good start for all of them. Since I am a girl and never really felt the "12 yr old boy friends" I didn't think it would relate to me as much but I was very wrong. The imagery was beautiful and it was somewhat believable. The jokes made me laugh out loud, all alone, in my computer room (I am listening to it behind this window as i type); especially the scene where Gordie shoots the garbage can and the jokes about the peoples "mothers" are hilarious too I make them all the time and I thought it was some new age thing but guess not! This is a 10 star film, no doubt, and completely worth seeing. I liked it more than the Godfather even. The language, even though people have found it too over-the-top, was hilarious. It's hilarious hearing these 12 yr old boys telling each other to f*** their moms because I've heard it all before and it's even funnier on camera. PLEASE WATCH THIS FILM YOU WILL NOT REGRET IT!

This is one of the most sentimental and ironic movies I've ever watched. We all know what happened to River Phoenix's character in the movie. It's ironic that he's death was a tragedy. Every time when I watch the ending where Chris chambers fades out, it reminds me of River phoenix. 8/10

review_title: A masterpiece about teenage boys coming of age

review_detailed_main: With out a dout one of the best comeing of ages movies.

review_title: One of the Greatest Stephen King Movies Ever Made
review_detailed_main: *Stand By Me is a movie that is best not to see before the age of fourteen.* Stand By Me is, with out a doubt, a classic. It has been parodied and referenced in all sorts of shows including Stranger Things and Family Guy. The music is classic and has a terrific score. "Stand By Me" by Ben E. King is a great song that wraps the movie up in bow. It is an incredibly well-made, character-driven, story. The acting is superb. The characters are foul-mouthed just like kids their age would be, which makes the story more realistic. The great cast coupled with everything else make this one of the greatest movies ever made.

Stand By Me is my favorite movie of all time. It's an amazing coming of age story about childhood friendship from director Rob Reiner, based on the Stephen King novella (the Body).

With an awesome young cast of, before they were stars, and a great rural setting out in the sticks, it's just as visually captivating as it is emotionally. It's got a great soundtrack, and the dialogue is unforgettable.

I have loved this movie for so many years, and seen it so many times, that I can't remember the first time I experienced this terrific film. But I can say that if you have not seen this movie, definitely check it out.

Stand by Me is one of my all time favourite films ever! The film captures everything a good film should have. All of the actors and actresses in the film were brilliant too. My favourite actor in the film was River Phoenix, he was amazing. It was a shame he died really. He could have gone on to great things and become one of the worlds most loved actors. Stand by Me is so realistic that it captures you and draws you in. It is a feel good film even though I wish that Chris didn't die in the film, I thought it was a sad way to finish a fantastic film. I hope in the future that another film will be made that is as good as Stand by Me. But I doubt it!

Stand by Me affected me greatly when I watched it as a kid, and it still has that effect on me as an adult. This group of kids reminds me of my friends growing up. We never sought out a dead body, but we had similar outdoor adventures and conversations before we grew apart. The acting feels genuine, the story is simple, yet compelling and the movie is one I'll never forget.

review_title: Quite Possibly The Best Coming-of Age Movie Ever Made.
i love this movie so much!!!!!
review_detailed_main:
i love this movie so much.

it has my favorite actor in it (jerry o connell) when he was a little chubbier and it's a great story i love the action drama and comedy of it all. gotta see this one for anyone who hasn't yet-candi

review_title: Best Coming of Age film ever!
review_detailed_main: This movie is an absolute classic! Movies about childhood and growing up don't get better than this. This movie never gets old, and I still rewatch it often due to the comfort it gives me. This is a nostalgic watch and it will forever stand the test of time and other coming of age movies. I'm a big SK fan too, so you pretty much get the point... :)

Stand by Me is probably the only Stephen King movie that surpassed the original story. I'm usually not impressed by the movies that result from books in general, but in this case, see the movie. From the cast of young talent to the narration of Richard Dreyfuss, who has the voice of Everyman (or Woman), this movie highlights what it was like to be a kid. I didn't grow up in the time frame of this movie, but I still felt a nostalgia for small-town life in the fifties. If I had to recommend one movie for everyone to see at least once, this would be the movie. And for anyone who thinks this is a movie about kids finding a dead body, think again: instead, this is a movie about kids finding out about themselves and the adults who have made differences, good and bad, in their lives.

review_title: Honest and powerful, Stand By Me is worth watching
review_detailed_main: An amazing adaption of Stephen King's, The Body. Set in the 1950's, Castle Rock, Oregan, a group of troubled youths set off in search of the body of a missing boy with the hope that their discovery will bring them fame. What started off as an adventure turned into a discovery of true friendship and of one's own character. What we see at the beginning are 4 simple, stereotypical characters; the smart one, the leader, the scared one and the funny one. However, throughout the course of the film we discover that the depth of their character runs deeper than anyone could have expected, as the boys travel further away from their suffocating home town, they're forced to reflect on their own reality.

This film is such a great film because it really captures what it is like to be a 12 year old kid. Simple storyline that blossoms with nostalgia for the viewer that can relate to the main characters. You can watch this film and remember the feeling that you had when you were with your friends at a young age. The film says it best when the narrator says something to the effect of " I never had friends like the ones I had when I was 12"
This is my favorite movie of all time. Watched it as a teen when it was new and still watch it today. It will not disappoint.

review_title: The childhood I wish I had
review_detailed_main:
This is one film I own on videotape and am not ashamed to say I watch again and again. It is, as others have said already, a classic.

As a fan in general of River Phoenix, I like especially to watch it every year around Halloween (or All Saints' Day, Nov. 1, for which Halloween is the vigil) in commemoration of his untimely death on Oct. 31. The enveloping setting for the film is the recollections of the grown-up writer Gordon LaChance of his close childhood friend, Chris Chambers, on reading in the newspaper of his sudden death. It is especially poignant to watch on the anniversary of the death of the actor who played Chris.

I would like to share a very touching and thought-provoking anecdote told by the author of "Lost in Hollywood", a biography of River Phoenix. During the filming of every movie in which he starred, River attached himself closely to someone else involved as a mentor and father figure. In the case of Stand by Me, this role was played by Robert Reiner, the director (who had wisely prepared his four principals before screening with adventure-wilderness-type activities of the same kind, in order to get them to "bond." It worked!)

During several takes of the "milk-money" confession scene, River had been unconvincing. Then Reiner asked River to think of a time in his own life when an adult had betrayed him. The result is what we see now-- what turns out to be one of the climactic moments of the film, although perhaps it needn't have been. And the biographer says that when the cameras stopped rolling, River's tears didn't. He kept sobbing and crying uncontrollably, until Reiner comforted him in his arms. Heaven only knows what had happened to River that he was recalling in that scene, but whatever it was was real.

whether you went in search of a dead body in the 1960s or played neighborhood flashlight tag in the 1980s, this film brings out a sense of nostalgia for all.

each one of us can connect in some level to one of the four brilliantly defined characters, as well as finding a best friend in another. the story line (although incredible and perhaps one of stephen king's best) is really irrellevant. rather than getting caught up in the story, one tends to find themselves caught up in the emotions, the rite of passage into manhood, and the slow decaying of times so sweet.

stephen king's words are not easily put into a movie, and few ever do the books justice. however, i believe this to the best rendition yet (yes, even beating out shawshank redemption).

rarely have i seen a movie that has moved me as much as this one. jesus, has anyone?

review_title: Quite possibly the GREATEST coming of age movie
review_detailed_main: Stand By Me has got to be one of the greatest coming of age movies ever made. Steven King's complex storytelling, blending characters back stories interspersed with Gordie's imagination, while telling the age old "quest saga" has the audience growing with the main characters and watching their childhood pass into young adulthood. It is a bittersweet journey for all involved. The gang leaves as childen, but return with an adult like view on life. Maybe it was because my friends and I were at the same age as the characters when this movie came out, but it really resonated with us. We could see ourselves in the gang. In a way, they were us and we were them.

I really love this movie. I think this movie should be viewed by all people in the world. It's themes are wonderful, true, sad, and a life-long lesson. I get chills every time that I watch this movie. It is such a wonderful account on life and the four young actors do a tremendous job with their performances. I think this movie should have definitely won Oscars. It is definitely Oscar potential and it is a shame that these actors were not more publicly known.

review_title: Best movie I have seen in a long time.
review_detailed_main: This movie is my favorite movie of all times. River Phoenix, Wil Wheaton, Corey Feldman, and Jerry O'Connell do a tremendous job in this movie. This movie brings back the childhood of every one who watches it. To get a taste of the 50s and early 60s, watch this movie!!! Or just to see some very good actors in action, watch it. Rob Reiner did an excellent job on this movie. This is his little gem!!!!

A brilliant rights of passage movie with an outstanding young cast, truly one of the best film adaptions of a Stephen King story to date. Also has a great soundtrack including Buddy Holly and Ben E. King. The Dialogue in this film is brilliant too. Especially the story of Lardass

review_title: Truly a masterpiece! i love it!
review_detailed_main: I saw this movie when i was younger and i still absolutley love it. the story itself is just brillant. the actors fit with charaters great! whil wheaton did a fabulos job playing the dramatic kid. river phoniex fit the bad boy with a soft heart image. corey feldman did an awesome job as the "big mouth" type of kid. and jerry o'connell did a treffic as the fat , not to smart but still funny kind of character! The movie let you see that even a boy or man can still cry. It had a great message. Simply the 4 boys ,who realy dont have much family, turn to the only people who can understand and help them in a time of need, their best friends. and its so sweet. This movie is and will always remain my favorite of ALL TIME! If you didnt enjoy this movie the first time watch it again and it will be your favorite too! God Bless.

review_title: Beautiful movie which made me think...
review_detailed_main:
I first watched this movie when I was about 13 - and I never forgot it. I never saw it again until about 5 months ago - I'm nearly 17 now.

I love this movie because as well as being well directed, well scripted and excellently cast, it made me think back to when I was 12 and the friends I had then. It made me realize that I didn't have friends like Gordie did.

"Friends come in and out of your life like busboys at a restaurant"

Can't get any truer than that.

'Stand by me' is a timeless coming-of-age movie that will remain in the memory of all who see it.

10 out of 10

review_title: They don't make movies like this anymore
review_detailed_main: Stand By Me a nostalgic remembrance of a friendship between four twelve year old boys, during a period when they're just young enough to talk about cartoons and be afraid of the dark, and old enough to use cuss words and smoke cigarettes, and their biggest childhood adventure. They all have their own emotional problems and that's what makes their friendship so endearing to the viewer. The plot revolves around Gordie, an adult now with kids of his own, writing about the summer when his group friends found out about the location of a boy's dead body, a boy they all knew. Believing that it's what will bring them at least local fame, they set out to be the first who discover it, in the end competing with a much older gang. Stand by me is one of those movies that, no matter your gender, how old you are or how many times you've already seen it, it moves you. It makes you think of your childhood friends, the ones you haven't seen or heard in a long time and wonder if they think about you too, from time to time. The summers you spent in their company, playing or searching for a grand new adventure or when the adventure found you. This movie has those type of characters that are easily to relate to, even as a grown up. A brilliant masterpiece with heartwarming insights , the ecranisation of Stephen King's novella "The Body" will stand the passing of time because in every generation, there will be people who would find a bit of themselves in it. I give it 10/10.

review_title: "stand by me" shows that children are more than capable of understanding, feeling and participating in previously described "adult concepts".
review_detailed_main: Modern "coming of age" Dramas seem to display notions of people under 15 years of age being innocents, free from corruption and unaware of tensions between associates of different sexes. Then along comes a catalyst in the shape of going to high school, making a new friend etc. and all of a sudden a child becomes an adolescent, free from illusions and aware of adult issues. Usually the "coming of age" drama is focused around these issues; of first noticing the opposite sex, of the discovery of a "generation gap" between the subject/s and their parents/guardians, of the discovery of swearing and drinking and occasionally drugs. The thing I liked about this movie is that it highlights the fact that awareness of these issues does not come exclusively with puberty. The characters in this movie smoke, swear, tell dirty jokes, discuss sex, and hate their parents all before hitting their "Teens". It shows that it is naive to assume that it takes 15 years for a child to realise that there is a "generation gap" existing in their household. It also displays an underlying concept that many children are capable of acheiving personal skills that many adults are incapable of; that is the ability to make decisions and stick to them, the ability to lead a group, the ability to take care of themselves, and the ability to problem solve within a group. This concept, that many children depend on their parents for economic support more than emotional support is an edgy one and one that forces veiwers to redefine their mental image of the "child".

review_title: The Beauty Of Childhood and Innocence
review_detailed_main:
This movie is really beautiful and is really a timeless masterpiece. Stephen King is known for having really interesting and developed characters in his novels and I think this is one of the best adaptations of one of his book that has ever been made.

It basically tells us the story of a group of four kids that start a journey looking for a dead body of a kid that is somewhere around the woods. But this is just the surface of the story. In fact is a story about the childhood, the friends and the innocence. Is a story that we can relate to easily, because we all have been childs at some moment and we had very good time back then, just playing with our friends, with no bigger worries than what kind of animal is Goofy, or what food would you choose if you could just pick one in the world.

The four kids are so great and the actors were perfect in the roles, like you really feel their friendship, their connection, their support to each other, but also you can see yourself grinning from the jokes they make, because they take you back to those moments with your friends in the past. Corey Feldman and Jerry O'Conell are really great in the movie and they provide most of the comic moments. But the true starts in here are Wil Wheaton and specially river Phoenix. They both have some very emotional scenes with each other that brought a tear to my eye more than I expected.

This movie has one of the most iconic shots in film history. The kids walking down the train tracks just singing a song with no worries at all. Some of the shots were stunning and really beautiful to look at and the movie has a really great soundtrack full of great hits from that time.

This is a movie that I think everybody could enjoy. I think this is in a more personal way but this movie touched me and made feel a bit sad and nostalgic about those lost moments in the past, but also made me happy because I was lucky to live that and to have really great friends. And I think I have never had any friends like the ones I had when I was twelve. But Jesus, who does?

review_title: I never had any friends later on like the ones I had when I was twelve.
review_detailed_main: Jesus, does anyone? Stand by Me is a timeless classic. A first class movie. When i'm flipping through the channels and i see this i stop and watch. River Phoenix would have been a giant. Corey Feldman wasted talent. Jerry O'Connell's first movie. Sincerely. Wesley Crusher found him a bit annoying.

This is how u do a rated R movie with kids! It captures the innocence of kids, very well. And when the kids make ridiculous stuff, you laugh instead of pissing u off. A movie that captures perfectly the feeling of nostalgia, friendship, life and changes. It's officially my fav coming-of-age movie.

review_title: Great performance from a young cast in this coming of age story from Stephen King...
Stand by Me is a film for everyone.
review_detailed_main: A timeless classic. An uplifting adventure for four young lads, with many obstacles in their path. Their mission is to find a dead body somewhere in the wilderness before anyone else does. It'll be their discovery, their stamp on history. It's a film for the masses, focusing on an age where childhood merges into adulthood. Will Wheaton's older self narrates (played by Richard Dreyfuss), explaining his relationships with his nearest and dearest. Stand By Me's continual themes of friendship, and dealing with problems way beyond your time are things we can all relate to. The four boys, Will Wheaton, Corey Feldman, Jerry O'Connell and River Phoenix have no trouble making Stephen King's novella a reality.

This movie is my favorite & one of the best movies I've seen in my life. The coming of age story is remarkable & the friendships are heartwrenching. The acting is wonderful from the four boys. I hope that everyone gets a chance to see these movies.

I watched this movie on the Disney channel when I was 11 years old. I was freaked out by the dead boy's body. I have never fogotten that movie. Years later, I picked up this movie to see it again with new eyes and to see it again for River Pheonix. When I was 11, I didn't know who this kid was in the movie. River plays Chris Chambers, probably the most interesting character next to DuChamp's and Ace's. River plays this character well, and so do all of the other actors in their roles. This movie is a classic with little flaws. I love it. See this movie for great drama, characters, jokes, and River Pheonix.

This is one of those movies that you are able to watch over and again. You will never tire from it. As I was growing up, around the same age as the actors, I was able to relate to much of what they were going through. Now, years later, the parallels have just become that much more profound.

one of the best movies ever made. rob reiner directed a great movie about four boys growing up an having an adventure finding a dead body(story by stephen king) the actors are great, especially RIVER PHOENIX.

This is one of the most classic films of all time. I don't know a single person who hasn't seen this film. And if I should ever come across one, I will generously let them borrow my copy so that they may have the great pleasure of seeing it. Based on the same Stephen King story collection that later gave rise to THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION. One of those great 'feel-good' movies. This one really does it, though.

Other recommendations would be THE SHAWSHANK REDEMPTION, THE GREEN MILE, THE MAJESTIC, HEARTS IN ATLANTIS, THE LEGEND OF BAGGER VANCE and OCTOBER SKY. All of them have that great thing to them that makes you feel all warm and fuzzy inside. Some people may like this feeling, others not. But, almost every person that I know has seen STAND BY ME and has enjoyed it immensely. Thank you Rob Reiner. The cast includes many great actors (only younger) such as Wil Wheaton (PYTHON), Jerry O'Connel (SCREAM 2), a much younger Keifer Sutherland (A FEW GOOD MEN) and the late River Phoenix. If you want a great movie that will touch your heart and stay with you forever, then see this one. "I wouldn't have missed a minute of it. Not for all the world"......5/5.

When i first heard of this movie, about 2 years ago, i thought it was gonna be stupid, but then my brother rented it and rented it over and over again and i just had to see what the big deal was, i loved this movie, it was hilarious, and the actors were great! This will always be one of my favoroite movies of all time!!!

This is my favourite film of all time. The story line helps the viewer envisage the times of when he/she were young, without responsibilities and always looking for adventure. Isn't it weird that everybody seemed to have 4 close friends when they were young and one of these being the most loyal you could wish for. Stand by Me is the epitome of everything that being young represented. The viewer is taken back to when they were young and whilst watching the film they also watch their past through the memories the film forces through, all from the relationship with your best friend to the fact that some friend do just become another face in the hall, even though you grew up and matured together. the whole experience forces you to watch it again and again even though every time it makes you sadder and sadder. its an extremely powerful film with 4 great actors acting superb. just wish there were more like it. 10/10
This was not one of my favourite Stephen King stories, but it was one of the best adaptations of his work. I enjoyed it.

I cannot believe this film doesn't have a higher rating with IMDb reviewers! My older brother had a '47 Studebaker while he was in high school (he graduated in 1958). He was not a "bad" kid, though he did have some behavioral problems as an adolescent (and as an adult, but he is someone to be proud of today). I don't know if he ever played "mail-box baseball or not: but if he and his friends didn't, it's only because they just didn't think of it!

review_title: best movie ever, fickle as i am, can't beat this one, period.
review_detailed_main: If you have not yet seen this movie you must. I think anyone who goes through they're life, especially childhood, without seeing this movie is seriously missing out ona great plot, great quotes, and great acting. The acting is so spectacular that i am inspired to try to become an actress myself. After watching this movie, River Phoenix's death was so much closer to the bone, he could've been larger than life and to me, and i bet lots of others, he already was in his short time on the earth. Wil Wheaton was the most adorable thing in the world in this movie and having seen picture of him today, he hasn't lost that cuteness he had in '86. Corey Feldman, awesome, just great, i wish he would appear in more stuff today, "The Lost Boys" and "Stand By Me" make you love him soo much, he just attaches to you. The characters are so real even if you're a girl, an adult, or a boy with a childhood exactly like this. The characters are so real, so undescribably cool and soooooo well portrayed. The actors are even more lovable because they are close to their characters, Rob Reiner (director of Stand By Me) says you must cast them that way because they have not "developed the craft [of acting]." So they really are like that!! It makes me so happy to know those guys are so real, very comforting in this new world of mondo-commercialization.

review_title: The four boys had different pathways but join as one.
review_detailed_main: The best thing about this movie was that it was about young male teenagers. It show a lot of various problems each character had, the story kept going through the movie. The screenplay would have been heaven for the actors, because Stephen King novel was breath taking. The director should go back to drama's because he did show each character's highs and lows. Pity this was River Phoenix best movie role.

This movie ranks as my favourite movie of all time. Through the eyes of the 4 youngsters, we are able to recapture the lost magic and innocence of youth. The plot develops smoothly to show the differences in the character of each boy, and how that affects their relationship. Each personality and character is also satisfactorily developed so we can gain an insight into the boys' thinking and actions.

It is really a nostalgic movie for me. Where can you find such friendships and relationships and adventures any more except maybe in the more rural and undeveloped areas?

Simplistic, but brilliant movie based upon Stephen King's short story. The atmosphere and mood are very special here and the characters King has created come to life in a very believable way. Performances by River Phoenix, Corey Feldman and Kiefer Sutherland are exceptionally good in my opinion.

review_title: The best coming of age movie of the eighties
review_detailed_main:
Rob Reiner is in my opinion an underrated director. Apart from "Stand by me" (1986), the film this review is about, he made other marvelous films such as "When Harry met Sallt" (1989), "Misery" (1990) and "A few good men" (1992).

"Stand by me" is an adaptation of a Stephen King novel (just as "Misery") whose original title was "The body". I understand the decision of Reiner to change the title. "The body" would have evoked an association with rancid coming of age films, a genre which the 1980s were already full of.

The new title is derived from the (very good) 50's soundtrack, but it contains also an ironic undertone. The film is about a couple of boys, about 12 years of age, at the end of the elementary school. Next year they will go to the high school, and due to differences in intelligence it is already obvious that they will go to different schools and not stick together.

During the adventure where the film is about they are however still together. In fact by revealing their most intimate secrets to each other they grow closer and closer to each other. In this respect the film resembles "The breakfast club" (1985, John Hughes), the other excellent teenage movie from the 80's.

"The breakfast club" is about 16-18 years old, in "Stand by me" the characters are some years younger. In "The breakfast club" the group consists of individuals of different social or political background, in "Stand by me" the group consists of individuals who, for some reason, are not popular guys. Being among each other they loosen up and are not afraid anymore to tell what really moves them.

In my opinion "Stand by me" is the best coming af age film of the eighties. It has a moving story, a pleasant soundtrack and the landscape from Oregon (not the mostly filmed State of the USA) is beautiful after all.

review_title: a reflection of life in a small town
review_detailed_main:
I'm not going to belabor the point everyone makes about this "genuine" story, how it's true-to-life, all that. Perhaps some people like this kind of life. Perhaps others didn't experience something different, but I, having grown up in two metropolitan cities, find the lives of young people portrayed here, well, empty and reminiscent of other "docu-dramas" like Kids. Indeed, even adults, as portrayed variously by the junk-yarder and his dog, and those at the pie-eating contest, are no more than grown-up teenagers.

Why is meth so pervasively destructive in rural counties and states from Kentucky to Kansas? Why are mass shootings disproportionately a suburban/rural phenomenon? I don't won't to cross the line here, but Stand By Me, while undoubtedly poignant and innocent, is deeply unsettling to me, simply because of that which made it great.

(Reviewed on Anniversary blu-ray) This is a tale that you will never forget, a story of childhood friendships that I am sure allot of people can relate to.

I have to first of all point out that the acting in this movie is absolutely terrific! You end up with a feeling of closeness to this band of four friends while at the same time really building a resentment towards the group of older good for nothings(with Kiefer Sutherland playing a fantastic bad guy). River Phoenix, for me, was the most outstanding actor in this movie, at times it was really hard to believe how mature his acting style was.

The movie is also shot very well with Rob Reiner doing a brilliant job of shooting every scene so that you are drawn into the action and really feel that you are along with the characters on a great journey both physically and emotionally. The back drop to this whole movie is also visually stunning.

Without going too much into the story as to spoil it, you can expect moments of action, suspense, heart warming stories and characters you will fall in love with, this movie does not have a boring moment in it, and even though the ending ties up the story absolutely perfectly I always find myself at the end of this movie wanting it to go on and never end. I also found it made me reflect on my own childhood friends and the adventures I had with them, which was a nice thing for a movie to do.

If you have a chance to watch this movie you should not pass it up! Its one you will never forget!

i honestly don't know why anybody would think that this was a bad movie. it was amazing. the theme was great and it was drawn out well. It was funny at the parts that it was trying to be. it was serious at the parts that it was trying to be. and it was sad at the parts that it was trying to be. from the other movies that I've seen, this is actually a pretty original movie. i mean... I've never seen one like this. I thought that river pheonix's acting was amazing and wil wheaton's character was well acted also. this is one of my favorite movies of all time and it deserves to be in the top 100. i know its in my top 10. i would recommend this movie to anybody. any age any sex an race. this is a MUST SEE.

Some of the finest acting performances I've ever seen, it's simply amazing watching them as if they were real life friends. The chemistry between the four boys were incredible, especially between River Phoenix and Wil Wheaton.

This movie certainly deserves its spot in the IMDB top 250.

I must have seen this film at least 30 times or more since i first watched it...

Its such a classic..

When i watched it over and over i just couldn't help but sing along to the soundtrack and get the feel of the film.... Its both entertaining and heartwarming... A great film about 4 friends who have the greatest 2 days of they're lives, along the way learning everything there is to know in life.. Turning them from kids to adults in a matter of moments...

When i watch it now i still get the feeling of nostalgia... The loss of contact of friends and the good times i had and things i did and how easily things can change....

But this is a great family film to watch and i will no doubt be watching it again so many times over the years........

IMDb Top 250: 177

What a sweet film. Even though I was born well after this film was released, the story of growing up and messing around with your friends is timeless- the times before the complications of life take hold.

The film follows four childhood friends on their summer trip to find a dead body, and the tolls the trip takes on them and the things they discover about themselves. The quest has many interesting stops, like a junkyard and one famous bridge. I loved the swamp scene.

You may not have been those kids who smoked and got into trouble, but one should be able to identify with the boys. Gordon is the worldly, smart one, living in his brother's shadow. Chris is the kid who has a rough family life, the physically mature one who acts as a big brother. Teddy is the crazy one, and Vern... well Vern was the one who you always wanted to shut up. How the hell was that kid your friend? The actors are fantastic. Though I couldn't stand Vern.

This film is a classic the moment you start watching it. All the staples of the rural 50's are here: the cars, the slick hair, the music and the lingo. It's fantastic. And then at the end with the skip to the 80's... 30 years is a long time.

Essentially, this film wants you to cherish your childhood. Ironically, with all the swearing, you probably won't see it until after that time is done. The memories this film extracts from your brain are vivid. Sweet, sweet nostalgia. Life and death and the coming of age are central to this very touching story. A wonderful film. 8.6/10

review_title: I Know I'll miss him forever
review_detailed_main: I LOVE this film, my favourite of all time. River is totally excellent as Chris, A troubled, but skilled teenager, who decides to choose the right path. This film is a story of 4 friend on an adventure looking for a dead kid's body. It is a tale of friendship, fear, grief and teenage problems. Superbly acted it gives all of us a look back on our lives, with fore than a few good laugh's.... you four eyed pile of sH**i...A pile of s**t has a thousand eyes. Classic!

review_title: How can we get nostalgic over times and places we've never been to?
review_detailed_main:
I wasn't expecting this film to explore such deep and emotional themes, with both universal and personal questions about friendships, brotherhood, fatherhood, insecurities, and just youth in general.

Despite being led by four kids, the film never felt annoying or cringey but was always full of warmth and excitement. The screenplay stands out both by its comedic strengths and its emotional depths. Lots of great landscapes and cinematography in the film that immerse us in the suburbs of small American towns of the '60s.

The film isn't really about the main plot of finding the body, that's just what's driving the characters as they learn more about themselves before they start a new chapter, and it's executed really well where you don't leave feeling dissatisfied, because it was never really about the body, but about their dynamics.

review_title: The best coming of age film you will ever see
review_detailed_main:
When i first saw the title i mistook it for a romantic film but it is not. It is a coming of age drama. As it is featured in IMDb's top 250 i had a lot expectations from it. And in the end it topped those expectations. It is such a movie which everyone is compelled to like.

I've seen this film 25 years after its initial release yet i've liked it so it is fair to say the appeal of this film stands tall to the test of time. Maybe the reason behind is that the main theme of the film is something which everyone relates to. It is Friendship. Maybe because of this reason you always feel deeply engrossed in this tale of friendship. That is why there is not even a single dull moment in the whole movie unlike many other highly acclaimed movies.

The story is rather simple maybe way too simple. But it is the execution, the genuine acting of the whole cast makes this movie such a delight to watch. I loved john Cusack who has a supporting role in the movie. His role as Gordon's brother is really well crafted though it is really short. Writing review about this movie and not mentioning River Phoenix would be injustice it is his role as the born leader of the group that gives this simple movie incredible depth.

So to summarize the movie is pretty good. Highly recommended and easily re-watchable. You will love every bit of the movie.

A very enthusiastic 8/10.

This movie brings forth all of the feelings of being a pre-teen and spending a summer of adventure with your friends. The bond between them is expertly portrayed and never overdone which i found rare. The acting of the four boys is superb and natural for the most part, Reiner did a wonderful job directing them. Speaking as a huge fan this is Phoenix at his pure best. Truly haunting. If you enjoy reminiscing then this is a great movie for you! The spectrum of emotions portrayed and invoked in this movie makes this one of the best to have come out of the eighties... Strike that, THE best. Add to all of this the fantastic music and the stunning scenery this is a must see.

This 1986 Rob Reiner classic is ALMOST among my top 5 of all time, but not quite as good as "Forrest Gump", the "Star Wars Trilogy", "Terminator 1&2", "The Blues Brothers", or "Braveheart", but it is unforgettable all the same. Four friends in the 50's go in search of a dead body. On the way there is much laughter of course(mostly contributed by Corey Feldman as crazy Teddy DuChamp and Jerry"Look how thin and good looking I am now"O'Connell as Vern the fat kid) but lots of sadness along the way. Wil Wheaton gives what is probably the most underrated performance of all time as sensitive budding writer Gordy, and River Phoenix has many fine moments as tough guy with bad reputation Chris Chambers. A fine supporting cast includes Richard Dreyfuss(one of my personal favorites), Marshall Bell, John Cusack, Casey Siemaszko(Charlie in "Young Guns"), Kiefer Sutherland, and Dick Durock, the "Swamp Thing" as Bill Travers. The Soundtrack is flawless too(if you look at all of my faves, excluding the "Terminator" flicks, they all have memorable soundtracks) with "Lollipop" By the Chordettes, "Stand By Me" By Ben E. King(the definitive version), "Everyday" By Buddy Holly, and "Great Balls of Fire" By Jerry Lee Lewis(Love that mailbox baseball!) just to mention a few. The tale of Davey Hogan must be one of the most memorably disgusting(funny) scenes in a movie up there with the fat man sequence(or organ donor transplant sequence, take your pick) in "Monty Python's The Meaning of Life"(Not as good as "Monty Python and the Holy Grail".

review_title: One of the great Love stories...
review_detailed_main: Before I saw the movie, I read the novella (THE BODY, by Stephen King) and was struck by the STYLE of the writing: it reminded me more than a little of a Ray Bradbury story. I enjoyed the story and looked forward to seeing the movie- but what I wasn't prepared for was the Emotional Impact the movie would have on me. When I walked out of the theater, my legs were weak. I went to my car and got in and sat behind the wheel for a long time thinking about the guys I'd grown up with. Most of them were dead or in jail by then (or should've been), but they'd been my FRIENDS and remembering them that evening, I couldn't help but break down. Sure, the movie is stylized and the dialogue retains that "Bradbury" feel, but STAND BY ME is one of those rare movies that (at least for me) sticks with you long after you've seen it. It's hard to watch because of the memories it dredges up, but I still see it whenever I can because sometimes, no matter how much it hurts, it's good to Remember.

Wow wat a great movie! I love the storyline young friends. And the music of the 50's is great. I have been to Stand By Me day on July 23 2015 in Brownsville Oregon and it was a amazing day. Nice to meet the people that also love this movie!

Ooooooh, how beautiful. I saw it when I was very young, but I watched it again about an hour ago and I'm still feeling a little sad. God, I don't think there will ever be another movie of that kind that lives up to its standards. The incredible acting and intense bonding really shine and the thing that really got me was River Phoenix. His character of Chris is one of the deepest, most touching characters I've ever seen.

God bless River, and let him rest in peace

review_title: Wonderfully done; one of the best Stephen King adaptations.
review_detailed_main:
Anchored by four irresistible performances by the youthful leads, "Stand by Me" stands tall as one of the finest films to be derived from a Stephen King story (a novella originally titled "The Body"). It's an emotionally stirring tale of boyhood friendship, at that transitional age before boys start making the journey towards manhood. And in that sense, this has an effectively allegorical quality. If the prospective viewer is anything like this one, it will likely make you long for your lost childhood. The four main characters are well defined and very sympathetic, with most of them having to experience some painful thoughts and ideas.

With Gordie (Wil Wheaton), it's the idea that his grieving parents have no love left for him after the death of his older brother Denny (John Cusack, in a cameo). With Chris (River Phoenix), it's the fact that he seemingly has a preordained destiny to end up a no-good type like his father and older brother "Eyeball" (Bradley Gregg). And Teddy (Corey Feldman) lives with an unbalanced, sadistic war veteran father who seriously maimed him at one point.

The setting is Oregon, 1960 (in the King-invented town of Castle Rock, which in his fiction is set in Maine). Together with their corpulent, nervous buddy Vern (Jerry O'Connell, in his film debut), the kids set out to search for the body of a kid their age, whom they heard had come to a bad end. Along the way they have assorted adventures: dodging a train, encountering a mean junk yard dog (who's nowhere near as monstrous as legend made him out to be), discovering a pond full of leeches, and being treated to one of storyteller Gordie's yarns (the entire Lardass Hogan episode is hysterical). Eventually, they run afoul of town bully "Ace" Merrill (an amusing Kiefer Sutherland).

The on location shooting is excellent, and the film does have a lot of resonance and emotional impact. Some people in the audience may take exception to the cussing (which really isn't all that bad), but director Rob Reiner, working from the script by co-producers Bruce A. Evans and Raynold Gideon, does a fine job of capturing small town America in a simpler time. Both Wheaton and Phoenix have some very impressive moments; backing up the young cast (also including Casey Siemaszko and Gary Riley) are such solid character players as Marshall Bell, Frances Lee McCain, and Bruce Kirby, with Richard Dreyfuss playing Gordie as an adult.

Reiner truly was on a roll during this period; 28 years later this remains one of his best efforts.

10 out of 10.

Great movie. It's one that I can watch over and over again. Great acting from very young actors. It's to bad we don't see these kind of actors now. River Phoenix Does a unbelievable job for a 14 year old. What a brilliant movie.

No matter what generation you came out of this movie is pure nostalgic fun. I was able to picture myself walking the railroad tracks in Tilbury with my friends. It reminded me of a hiding spot, along the tracks, a few kilometers outside of town. Unfortunately, there was no dead body in our hiding spot.

review_title: Suck my fat one, you cheap dime store hood!!!!
review_detailed_main: Great line for one great movie! This is a beautifully constructed coming of age movie that everyone should see(preferably once when your 12 and once afterward). It has all the ingredients that this kind of movie needs (i.e. great friendships, innocence, gangs, River Phoenix). Add to this the tender direction from Reiner, the great 50's music, just-right-narrative from Dreyfuss and all the superb young actors and you have a classic that deserves to be in the IMDB top 200. Oh......one more thing:TRAIN!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
It's a really good and funny movie! it's cute as well. i recommend it for a night where you're feeling down and want a good laugh!

This is a fabulous feel good movie in the same vein than our french « Cesar, 9 years old » : both have the amazing ability to find again the child you were a long time ago ! For me, it's even get more emotional as Gordie looks a bit like the me : fragile, skinny, soft, dreamy, mournful, anxious, a great imagination to invent stories and definitely attached to his friends. Like him, i was demolished when education separated me from them ! Like him, i like having adventures and i have also covered a corpse (mine was a dead cat in a decrepit hospital for which we got troubles with parents !!!). So King has really a gift to remember this golden time with his words and finally, he could leave the paranormal ! His buddy are all fantastic and their chemistry feels good ! To put it in the late 50s makes it share this mythic time with rock songs (especially the eponymous classic) and perfect nostalgic society (« twin peaks », « BTF ») and this trip into wild nature is just a fantastic journey that my city slickers soul craves for ! Thus, definitely, the best movie for 1986 forever !

If you feel lonely and depressed, this is the film to watch. This great film of a unique friendship reminds you what it was like to be a kid hanging out with your friends, going on adventures etc.

I have probably watched this film over 20 times, and it is still as good as it was the first time I watched it, the "magic" is still there.....

Great performances, great actors and a great atmosphere (which seem to fill you with some kind of happiness). River Phoenix is terrific. The conversation pieces are brilliant, and several phrases will sit in my head forever.

This has always been, and will always be, my favorite movie of all time. I've grown up with this movie, and it has influenced me to become a screenwriter. I only hope that I can someday write something that is as good, and affecting as this film. It has the best performances by a young cast in the history of cinema. In addition, it has just the right blend of comedy and drama. How can you not love this movie?

review_title: Perfect coming of age movie for teens and adults
review_detailed_main:
This movie depicts 4 elementary school children, but the mature manner by which they behave by today's standards makes them more relatable to teens. Heck this "coming of age" movie's rated R.

But it is wonderfully entertaining. It has Stephen king all over it, but it's filled with both comedic and sentimental dialogue. Despite the premise or finding a dead corpse or the countless sex jokes, the film's message that childhood is the golden era of friendship is undeniably heartwarming. But if that sounds too cliche, the movie is filled with an unsettling atmosphere of impending peril, which is reason enough to watch it. The ending was realistic and worthy of respect. Best coming of age movie I've ever seen.

Stand by me is a classic and deserves it! Even as The plot itself isn't very deep, interesting, or even new. Four boys go out searching for a dead body, because it seems thrilling to them. That's basically it.

But, what the movie makes out of this premise is incredible. The characters are so well drawn, the scenery ranges from beautiful to frightening, the acting is superb, the actions are mostly believable, the heroes are relatable as it gets, the soundtrack matches, and the movie hits all the right spots on your soul.

Stand by me grips you right at the heart and plays on any string available. The warming friendship, simple life, and pure joy only young boys can experience (before they discover girls). The highs and lows of growing up, and even the sadness of getting older and dying.

Life itself has so many to offer and so does Stand by me. After finishing this movie many viewers may have laughed, bathed in nostalgia, and even cried at the end.

Only the villains Fall a Bit Short. They are too much of a cliche.

My earliest memories of this film are of my sister going through a huge River Phoenix phase just after he died and watching this film over and over again. A while ago I remembered it and watched it and now I can't get enough. I'm only 15, so this film has really affected me and made me view my friendships in a different light. Oh and River Phoenix is luuuuuuush!
Although the movie can occasionally start to lean on more of the sappy side, it's still a beautiful explorations of friendship and the loss of innocence.

Everyone makes judgmental thoughts about others. Whether we actually care about these prejudices or not is personal, but Stand By Me inspiringly documents that we can transcend the labels on us, and further demonstrates that we should.

Four young boys are searching for fun, for adventure, for a memorable experience. Upon hearing the shocking news of the location of a missing boy's body, they set out on a venture to find him and have their pictures in the newspapers. Throughout the journey, they discover a lot more--about themselves and the world--besides the ill-fated boy.

This film is extremely nostalgic. Displaying the lives of adventurous and curious boys in the summer, who have been devoid of attention. These four twelve-year-old boys have experienced a great fortune of pain throughout their lives already, and they begin a trek to escape from their past for at least a short while.

The whole movie revolves around the theme of friendship and overcoming challenges. We see the various emotions the boys feel, the suffering they undergo, and the will power that they have to be themselves. I truly enjoyed this Stand By Me since it's not your typical film of an adventure through the lands; no, it's an inspirational story of four boys who start the epoch of their lives.

We all have personal trials that we go through. It could be the untimely death of a loved one, finding meaning in life, battling depression or just finding a purpose to live. Regardless of the challenges we endure, this film strongly depicts how vastly we transform and learn about ourselves when faced with controversy.

I could watch this film any day of the week there are so many things that are fun happening it is hard to believe Stephen King master of horror wrote this, stars of the future were on show, it is the definitive movie of growing up and how scary and fun it can be all at the same time

review_title: One of the most honest movies about growing up ever!
The best film of all time
review_detailed_main: Every now and then, a movie comes along that you carry in you heart forever. I first saw this movie when I was about seven. After several years had passed, I rented it again, and could not believe what I saw on the screen. It was this perfect movie, the actors were brilliant as was the writing and directing. I was about the same age as the characters, and I related to their feelings and emotions. It had parts that made me laugh (the campfire scene), parts that made me cry (the milk money scene) and parts I will never forget ( "I'll see you around." "Not if I see you first."). This movie touched my heart like no other movie has before. It is THE coming-of-age movie. No one has made a better one, and I don't think they ever will.

review_title: An excellent coming of age movie...

review_detailed_main:
I watched a part of Stand By Me on TV and I liked what I saw so I went and bought the film. SBM is a coming of age film and still is popular after 20 years, even if it was before my time, I loved it and watched it every chance I get. This film stars River Phoenix, Jerry O'Connell, Corey Feldman and Wil Wheaton, as anyone would say, these 4 boys were incredibly talented and really put 101% into their characters and really lived in the film, doing what any young boys would've done at 12-16. They can easily relate to the film because they're not far off from their character's age hence they can act like boys with cussing, smoking and fights.

The storyline is true and how they put a meaning into the film about friendship and how people don't have friends like the ones when they were twelve, that sure is true! This is a movie to see before you die, if you choose not to see it, then you're missing out on a classic movie.
